story:
A kids museum

I live in Toronto. I'm a business person.  I have a young child.  And sometimes, well, it can be a struggle.  Sound familiar? I want the best things for my child: to foster her growth in a positive, hands-on way and to fill her time with creative exploration.  Isn't that what being a kid should be about?  Especially all those "firsts", the ones that happen when kids are under 6 years old?  We need options.  The frantic pace of modern life, the easy distractions of video screens, travel times, TTC routes, admission prices, daycare wait-lists...they all make it harder than it needs to be.

When my daughter and I visited a "children's museum" in San Francisco, we were amazed.  So many young families interacting in a fun, large, unstructured space geared for kids just like mine!  So inclusive and accessible.  So focused on play, exploration and discovery...at a kids' natural pace.  I discovered over 200 North American cities with a Children's Museum, places for young kids to learn about themselves and the world.  But Toronto has no such place.  I was inspired, and began a mission to bring a "children's museum" to downtown Toronto.  The Children's Discovery Centre !

Why Toronto?

Toronto is the fastest growing city in North America, and it's enjoying a baby-boom.  A new generation is choosing to stay in the city, according to Stats-Canada, tripling the number of young families living downtown in the next 5 years.  From 2006-2011, the number of 0-4 year olds living south of Queen St jumped 55%.  Demand for family-focused and family-friendly services, products, amenities and lifestyle experiences is ramping up!  The ROM, AGO and Ontario Science Centre are great, but more suitable for older kids.  One in five Toronto kids have access to licensed day-care at the pre-school level...with even fewer options for those downtown.  So if an urban toddler is not in day-care, where do they explore?  Where do they get messy? Where do they build their brains?

The Children's Discovery Centre provides our youngest citizens with a dynamic, hands-on environment for unstructured play and exploration.

The Children's Discovery Centre will be located at  

45 Stratchan Avenue. 

Beside Liberty Village.  

@ the corner of Strachan & Ordinance, just south of King St.


What happens there?

The 20,000 square foot facility is made up of 10 themed Discovery Zones, plus baby-friendly quiet rooms and a feeding area, a snack cafe and a party room.

Mini-City

The 10 Discovery zones are each designed to foster imagination and free-play with a different aspect of life in Toronto.  Kids, parents/caregivers can wander in and out of each zone at will, with no set "rules" for how to play in any area.  Children are not directed to play in certain ways with certain items.  They are free to get messy and create what they want!

The Discovery Zones are:

  1. Mini-City:  a small scale "city", complete with painted roads, street signs, tricycles, construction and a gravel pit.  Kids get active here!
  2. Art Hive:  crayons, clay, paint, easels, paper, squeegees.  Kids get messy here!
  3. Make Believe:  costumes, puppets, a stage, mirrors and mats.  Kids build characters and dance here!
  4. Boom Room:  drums, mallets, bongos, bells.  Kids make 'music' here, sometimes with household items!
  5. Pet Vet:  stethoscopes, doctor toys, lab coats, 'x-rays' and your own stuffed creatures.  Kids love animals and learn empathy here!
  6. Eat Street:  a mini-grocery store with shopping carts and produce PLUS mini-kitchens with stoves, pots, pans, aprons and utensils. Kids play with food here!
  7. Campground: rocks, logs, a canoe, magnifying glasses, tents and a 'campfire'. Kids explore nature here!
  8. Imagination Station: kid-sized large foam blocks in amazing shapes that lock together.  Kids build and create here!
  9. Storyland: books, colours, pillows and nooks.  Kids learn words and listen here!
  10. First Discoveries: bright colours, soft textures, easy landings. The smallest kids crawl here!  Caregivers and parents share and connect here!

 Campground

Eat Street


What We Need  

We've been at this for nearly two years already. And while we've raised enough  to secure use of an actual, 20,000 square foot building in Garrison Point (beside Liberty Village), we need a bit more to FILL the place with all the right stuff:  the materials, the paint, the toys and the experts to ensure we're delivering on our promise to inspire our youngest children through creative play.

In this campaign we are raising $80,000 to outfit the ten Discovery Zones of the centre.  That is, $8K for each zone to go directly into the purchase and installation of the materials, equipment, decor, tools, textures and colours.

If we exceed this goal, we will simply make each area even better, with funds directed at additional materials, more frequent fresh change-outs and higher-quality items.  

Our campaign IS flexible, however, and should we fall short of the target, we will still allot the funds to the Discovery Zones.  Our $80K target is based on our curated list of equipment and items needed for discovery at the centre.

What You Get for contributing

We believe the best perk lies in exploring the new space!  So our perks are mostly designed to ensure those that open their wallets get to open the doors at the Children's Discovery Centre.  But there's also some fantastic events that go with the launch, and we hope to see you there!  

The Impact

The Children's Discovery Centre (CDC) is designed for anyone with young kids under 6 years old looking for "something to do" or "somewhere to go" that is inspiring, engaging and educational. Not just the park or the shopping mall. It's a great new resource for young families...bringing new ideas in child education for:

  • moms and dads on mat/pat leave
  • families 
  • nannies and caregivers
  • school and daycare groups
  • grandparents
  • tourists and Toronto visitors

Challenges

It's a big undertaking.  So we're tackling it in stages.  The May launch of the Children's Discovery Centre (CDC)  in Toronto represents "stage 1", as we inhabit our temporary space at Garrison Point, beside Liberty Village for a five-month run.  Then we'll move our concept and each Discovery Zone to a permanent home - still in the downtown core! Planning is happening now.  Success is a function of attendance and financial viability.  But construction is underway, and we launch this May!

It's important to know the CDC is a grassroots initiative.  All the effort, time and funding needed is coming from regular people and some great business leaders.  That means it's:

  • not government funded
  • not a corporately initiative
  • not a charity

Pass it along  

Regardless of any financial help you can give, please pass this campaign on to people you know! Use the awesome Indiegogo share tools or just forward the link to your friends (KidsDiscoveryTO). Together we can build something for Toronto families, something that's missing.  Something kids will love.

Thanks so much. Hope to see you at the Children's Discovery Centre!

Feedback? Please contact us at urbarn@mac.com with any feedback & questions.

Who's involved?

The Centre is designed by an expert Advisory Council of leading primary education teachers, early childhood development professionals and parents:

Jeanhy Shim :  founder, Children's Discovery Centre

  • highly respected and passionate city builder, involved in over 500 real estate projects throughout the GTA over the past 22 years as developer, advisor or consultant
  • specialist in strategic market research, product design and development, land acquisitions or sales and marketing
  • founder of Housing Lab Toronto - a catalyst in rethinking how we grow Toronto and make it a more liveable place for all (including her six year old daughter!)

Geraldine Mabin : Head Advisor 

  • internationally recognized leader in the field of early childhood education
  • founder of The Mabin School (1980), Children’s Own Museum (1998), Words in Motion (2004) and Friendship in Action (2013) consultant to several schools world-wide

Nancy Brown : Advisory Council 

  • highly respected educator and professor in the field of childhood development
  • award-winning consultant and designer of Spiral Garden (Holland Bloorview Kids Rehabilitation Hospital, 1984), C.A.R.E. Program at Trinity Bellwoods (1992), and several children's art education experiences at the Art Gallery of Ontario

Paola Cohen : Advisory Council 

  • early childhood educator recognized for her pioneering role in the field of arts education and childhood development
  • instrumental in shaping the arts curriculum for children at the Institute of Child Study at the University of Toronto, Visual Arts Department in the University of Toronto Faculty of Education, and The Mabin School

Stacie Carroll : Advisory Council 

  • early childhood educator and award-winning teacher with the Toronto District School Board
  • specialist in teaching kindergarten children with developmental disabilities
  • Recipient of the 2012 Prime Minister's Award for Teaching Achievement
  • co-developer of a communication app for those with an expressive language delay

Laila Baksh : Advisory Council 

  • certified early childhood educator, certified child & youth worker
  • currently head of the ECE program at St. Stephen’s Harbourfront Child Care Centre, responsible for curriculum & programming for babies, infants and toddlers from 6 months to  five years

Lili Lipton : Advisory Council 

  • certified early childhood educator and teacher with the York Region District School Board
  • specialist with students of various developments abilities, including Autism, Aspergers, learning and behavioural exceptionalities

Sarah Patterson : Advisory Council 

  • certified child life specialist with the Hospital for Sick Kids
  • co-director of the Pediatrics Dept. Child Life Studies programme at McMaster University
  • early childhood development instructor at Ryerson University and George Brown College

Simone Atungo : Advisory Council 

  • prominent community advocate and leader specializing in community health research, policy and program outreach and integration, most notably with Mount Sinai Hospital, Parkdale Community Health Centre, and now Toronto Community Housing

Lianne Phillipson-Webb : Discovery Zone Curator

  • registered nutritionist, author and founder of Sprout Right: Nutrition from Tummy to Toddler
  • resident nutrition expert on Canada AM, CHCH Morning Live, Global Morning Live and CityLine
  • regular contributor to Today’s Parent, Canadian Family, TheLoop.ca and iVillage.ca. 

Thom Sokoloski : Discovery Zone Curator

  • highly respected artist, curator, producer and creative consultant who is a recognized and leading authority on contemporary art, performance and community engagement through art
  • over 40 years of local, national and international experience, including Luminato, Nuit Blanche, World Stage, Musica Festival in Strasbourg, Holland Festival, Art Toronto, Socrates Sculpture Park in New York, Opéra de Montréal, Café de la Danse, LaMama NYC, Canadian Opera Company and the ROM

Vandana Taxali : Discovery Zone Curator

  • arts & media attorney
  • recognized art agent, curator and mentor involved in NXNE (2013), The Artist Project (2014), King East Design District (2014), OCAD Imagination Catalyst, the Empowered Youth Startup Hub and Toronto Startup Weekend
 Laura Aaron : Discovery Zone Curator

  • super creative and experienced producer of cultural events, debates, and activations bringing leading thinkers and industry leaders together to examine big ideas, issues, and trends
  • curator of the Fernie Independent Film Series
  • co-founder of the Reel Canadian Film Festival


Feedback? Please contact us at urbarn@mac.com with any feedback & questions.
story_txt:
A kids museum I live in Toronto. I'm a business person.  I have a young child.  And sometimes, well, it can be a struggle.  Sound familiar? I want the best things for my child: to foster her growth in a positive, hands-on way and to fill her time with creative exploration.  Isn't that what being a kid should be about?  Especially all those "firsts", the ones that happen when kids are under 6 years old?  We need options.  The frantic pace of modern life, the easy distractions of video screens, travel times, TTC routes, admission prices, daycare wait-lists...they all make it harder than it needs to be.
When my daughter and I visited a "children's museum" in San Francisco, we were amazed.  So many young families interacting in a fun, large, unstructured space geared for kids just like mine!  So inclusive and accessible.  So focused on play, exploration and discovery...at a kids' natural pace.  I discovered over 200 North American cities with a Children's Museum, places for young kids to learn about themselves and the world.  But Toronto has no such place.  I was inspired, and began a mission to bring a "children's museum" to downtown Toronto.  The Children's Discovery Centre !





Why Toronto?
Toronto is the fastest growing city in North America, and it's enjoying a baby-boom.  A new generation is choosing to stay in the city, according to Stats-Canada, tripling the number of young families living downtown in the next 5 years.  From 2006-2011, the number of 0-4 year olds living south of Queen St jumped 55%.  Demand for family-focused and family-friendly services, products, amenities and lifestyle experiences is ramping up!  The ROM, AGO and Ontario Science Centre are great, but more suitable for older kids.  One in five Toronto kids have access to licensed day-care at the pre-school level...with even fewer options for those downtown.  So if an urban toddler is not in day-care, where do they explore?  Where do they get messy? Where do they build their brains?
The Children's Discovery Centre provides our youngest citizens with a dynamic, hands-on environment for unstructured play and exploration.
The Children's Discovery Centre will be located at  
45 Stratchan Avenue. 
Beside Liberty Village.  
@ the corner of Strachan & Ordinance, just south of King St.

What happens there?
The 20,000 square foot facility is made up of 10 themed Discovery Zones, plus baby-friendly quiet rooms and a feeding area, a snack cafe and a party room.


Mini-City
The 10 Discovery zones are each designed to foster imagination and free-play with a different aspect of life in Toronto.  Kids, parents/caregivers can wander in and out of each zone at will, with no set "rules" for how to play in any area.  Children are not directed to play in certain ways with certain items.  They are free to get messy and create what they want!
The Discovery Zones are:


Mini-City:  a small scale "city", complete with painted roads, street signs, tricycles, construction and a gravel pit.  Kids get active here!

Art Hive:  crayons, clay, paint, easels, paper, squeegees.  Kids get messy here!

Make Believe:  costumes, puppets, a stage, mirrors and mats.  Kids build characters and dance here!

Boom Room:  drums, mallets, bongos, bells.  Kids make 'music' here, sometimes with household items!

Pet Vet:  stethoscopes, doctor toys, lab coats, 'x-rays' and your own stuffed creatures.  Kids love animals and learn empathy here!

Eat Street:  a mini-grocery store with shopping carts and produce PLUS mini-kitchens with stoves, pots, pans, aprons and utensils. Kids play with food here!

Campground: rocks, logs, a canoe, magnifying glasses, tents and a 'campfire'. Kids explore nature here!

Imagination Station: kid-sized large foam blocks in amazing shapes that lock together.  Kids build and create here!

Storyland: books, colours, pillows and nooks.  Kids learn words and listen here!

First Discoveries: bright colours, soft textures, easy landings. The smallest kids crawl here!  Caregivers and parents share and connect here!



 Campground
Eat Street

What We Need  
We've been at this for nearly two years already. And while we've raised enough  to secure use of an actual, 20,000 square foot building in Garrison Point (beside Liberty Village), we need a bit more to FILL the place with all the right stuff:  the materials, the paint, the toys and the experts to ensure we're delivering on our promise to inspire our youngest children through creative play.
In this campaign we are raising $80,000 to outfit the ten Discovery Zones of the centre.  That is, $8K for each zone to go directly into the purchase and installation of the materials, equipment, decor, tools, textures and colours.


If we exceed this goal, we will simply make each area even better, with funds directed at additional materials, more frequent fresh change-outs and higher-quality items.  
Our campaign IS flexible, however, and should we fall short of the target, we will still allot the funds to the Discovery Zones.  Our $80K target is based on our curated list of equipment and items needed for discovery at the centre.

What You Get for contributing
   We believe the best perk lies in exploring the new space!  So our perks are mostly designed to ensure those that open their wallets get to open the doors at the Children's Discovery Centre.  But there's also some fantastic events that go with the launch, and we hope to see you there!

moms and dads on mat/pat leave
families 
nannies and caregivers
school and daycare groups
grandparents
tourists and Toronto visitors

   Challenges  It's a big undertaking.  So we're tackling it in stages.  The May launch of the Children's Discovery Centre (CDC)  in Toronto represents "stage 1", as we inhabit our temporary space at Garrison Point, beside Liberty Village for a five-month run.  Then we'll move our concept and each Discovery Zone to a permanent home - still in the downtown core! Planning is happening now.  Success is a function of attendance and financial viability.  But construction is underway, and we launch this May!






It's important to know the CDC is a grassroots initiative.  All the effort, time and funding needed is coming from regular people and some great business leaders.  That means it's:



not government funded
not a corporately initiative
not a charity



Pass it along  

Regardless of any financial help you can give, please pass this campaign on to people you know! Use the awesome Indiegogo share tools or just forward the link to your friends (KidsDiscoveryTO). Together we can build something for Toronto families, something that's missing.  Something kids will love.
Thanks so much. Hope to see you at the Children's Discovery Centre!Feedback? Please contact us at urbarn@mac.com with any feedback & questions.

story:
Our mission is to identify people who are struggling with student loan debt and help them pay off their loans more quickly.  Let us make the case for joining our movement…

THE ISSUE

Debt is a trap, especially student debt, which is enormous, far larger than credit card debt.  It’s a trap for the rest of your life because the laws are designed so that you can’t get out of it.” – Noam Chomsky

Total outstanding student debt in the US stands at $1.2 trillion.  This number represents a full spectrum of impact, as recent college grads to senior citizens are struggling with student loan debt.  Over forty percent of borrowers are in deferment or forbearance where payments are suspended but interest continues to accumulate; making future payments higher and more difficult to manage.  More than ten percent of borrowers have already spiraled into default and at 6% - 8% interest rates, many more will follow.  There is no easy way out as private lenders may garnish wages, freeze bank accounts, circumvent Social Security benefits, and place liens on personal property.  Further, the debt cannot be discharged through bankruptcy.

The MPOL team was spurred to action by the reality that recent grads (regardless of their age), who have faced the highest cost of education, will enter a job market that is underperforming in terms of wages.  They will endure high interest rates on significant loans.  Many will make income-adjusted payments only to find the loan growing, despite their best efforts.  It is a tough and complicated issue, but we are ready for the challenge! And until there is legislative change, we want to do our part to help.  Please join our movement.

                                     

WHAT IS MISSION: PAID OFF LETTER?

Mission: Paid Off Letter (MPOL) is a grassroots movement dedicated to a simple, yet powerful effort-

HELP BORROWERS PAY OFF THEIR STUDENT LOANS MORE QUICKLY

  Often times, borrowers are facing such burdensome loans that a payoff seems impossible and default looms like a dark cloud.  It can feel like a prison.  Our organization is poised to shine the light of hope and self-empowerment by providing tactical solutions for attacking the debt from many angles, ultimately arriving at that payoff letter!

One caveat – this is NOT a magic pill- poof, and the debt is gone!  The MPOL program is designed for responsible borrowers who are determined to drive through the debt more quickly and move on to more productive uses of their income.  It is a process.


THE PILOT/PROOF OF CONCEPT

The MPOL Program is designed to be:

Goal-driven.  Solution- oriented.  Pragmatic.

And here’s how we’re going to get it done…

Your donation to Mission: Paid Off Letter will enable us to launch a pilot to prove our concept works.  We will start with a sophisticated website that accepts online submissions. Next, we will identify participants for our pilot, using the following criteria:

-  Borrowers whose student loan debt is 100% - 200% of their annual income

-  Loan is in repayment status (conventional or income-adjusted)

     We will give you time to end your deferment or forbearance, if accepted to our     program.

-  The applicant is currently employed

-  Compelling essay that tells the applicant’s story and expresses their need

-  Letters of recommendation from personal, professional, and academic sources

-  No age limit

Our Board of Directors will then distilled the applicants down to five - ten participants who will enter the MISSION: PAID OFF LETTER program.  It will be a two - three year journey. 

During that period, our team will:


1)  Make two – three additional payments to MPOL participants’ student loans every year for a two - three years.  This will kick a significant dent in the loan, as additional payments (that are not income-adjusted) go directly toward principal.

2)  Give MPOL participants FREE access to a financial counselor who will help them create a budget and find ways to squeeze more money out there current income to put toward the loan.  Every extra dollar will help shrink the debt.

3)  Match MPOL participants with top-notch job recruiters to ensure they are in the optimal job for their skills and education level with an aim toward earning more to make bigger loan payments.

Note that the impact of making additional loan payments is SIGNIFICANT:
"If you have a 4 percent fixed interest rate on a $200,000 loan and make one $500 payment toward principal once a year, you will save a total of $12,190 in interest payments over the life of the loan and it would end just over 2 years earlier. If that same loan were at 6 percent, you would save $22,830 and the loan would end a full 2.5 years earlier." - SFgate.com

After graduating from our program, MPOL participants will have made HUGE progress toward paying off their student loan and YOUR donation will have gotten them there!

FUNDRAISING GOALS:

Here's how will use our Indiegogo campaign funds:

First, we will build infrastructure- website, team, operations, accounting, etc.  Next, we will shift our focus to procuring the first group of participants, which will require a thorough selection process.  We will then build and execute our three-point program (above).

We expect to show tangible results within the first year with our first group of participants.  This will enable us to raise money on a continual basis and enroll our second group…potentially running several MPOL groups concurrently!



Should we go beyond $250K; THEN WE HAVE A MAGIC PILL!  This is where we pay off the student loan of 1 - 3 of our early participants, literally giving them a clean slate.  The money they’ve spent on loan payments can go toward a house or starting a business or simply living their dream.  This is our BIG DREAM and we need your help to get there!

Any money remaining from reaching/exceeding the stretch goal will be used for subsequent years of operation.


BASIC OPERATING BUDGET BREAKDOWN:

The general consensus is that a non-profit should spend 70% of gross income on its program or service and 30% on staff, admin, and fundraising.  As a start-up, our numbers may be skewed during Years 1 and 2, but we plan to be on track by Year 3.

These charts depict our anticipated use of funds:

Each year, we will strive to become more efficient, enabling us to spend more of our resources on the program itself.  Most importantly, by Year 3, we will have a self-sustaining, cost-efficient fundraising platform that supports the longevity of our organization.  We’re up for the challenge of creating a stellar non-profit that changes lives!

FAQs:

1) Will my donations be tax deductible?

A: Yes!  MPOL is a newly established not-for-profit organization incorporated in Illinois.  We are in the process of establishing federal tax exemption for MPOL.  The great news is that tax exemption is retroactive, and we will be able to keep 100% of your donation, even if exemption is not granted until later this year.  We anticipate completing this process by early fall and sending a donation letter to you by Oct or Nov for 2015 tax purposes.

2) When will I receive my perk?

A: You will receive your perk 30 – 45 days after the campaign ends.  This will give us time to print the t-shirts, canvas totes, etc., and ship them.  Thank you for your patience!

3) What will the perks look like?

A: We are proud of our perk products!  Please take a look below.


Our perk partner is Venley.  Check out their site at wearvenley.com

4) Is shipping included?

A: Yes, if you live in the US.  For international donors, please add your specified shipping after you choose your perk.

5) How do I choose the size of my t-shirt?

A: No worries, we will contact you before shipping.

6) What if I want to donate, but I don’t want a perk?

A: MPOL appreciates your support for our campaign and we welcome your donation even if you do not wish to receive a perk. That just means 100% of your donation will go directly to our program!

7) Who created the graphics and video?
A: Our Team Members, Brittney Hurley and Lawrence Brown, created the video and campaign graphics.  They are super talented and thorough.  To contact them, click on the "See More Details" link under the video at the top of the page.  There, you will find all of the MPOL team members.

8) What if I wish to donate by check?

A: Yes! Please make your check out to "Mission: Paid Off Letter."

Our PO BOX is:

3011 W 183rd Street

Unit 302 

Homewood, IL 60430

skewed during Years 1 and 2, but we plan to be on track by Year 3. These charts depict our anticipated use of funds:


Each year, we will strive to become
more efficient, enabling us to spend more of our resources on the program
itself.  Most importantly, by Year 3, we will have a self-sustaining,
cost-efficient fundraising platform that supports the longevity of our
organization.  We’re up for the challenge of creating a stellar non-profit
that changes lives!

FAQs:

1)
Will my donations be tax deductible?
A: Yes!  MPOL is a newly
established not-for-profit organization incorporated in Illinois.  We are in the process of establishing federal tax exemption for MPOL.  The great news is that
tax exemption is retroactive, and we will be able to keep 100% of your
donation, even if exemption is not granted until later this year.  We
anticipate completing this process by early fall and sending a donation
letter to you by Oct or Nov for 2015 tax purposes.
2)
When will I receive my perk?
A: You will receive your perk 30 – 45
days after the campaign ends.  This will give us time to print the
t-shirts, canvas totes, etc., and ship them.  Thank you for your patience!
3)
What will the perks look like?
A: We are proud of our perk
products!  Please take a look below.


Our perk partner is Venley. 
Check out their site at wearvenley.com
4)
Is shipping included?

A: Yes, if you live in the US. 
For international donors, please add your specified shipping after you choose
your perk.
5)
How do I choose the size of my t-shirt?
A: No worries, we will contact you
before shipping.
6)
What if I want to donate, but I don’t want a perk?
A: MPOL appreciates your support for
our campaign and we welcome your donation even if you do not wish to receive a
perk. That just means 100% of your donation will go directly to our
program! 7) Who created the graphics and video?A: Our Team Members, Brittney 
Hurley and Lawrence Brown, created the video and campaign graphics.  They are super talented and thorough.  To contact them, click on the "See More Details" link under the video at the top of the page.  There, you will find all of the MPOL team members.8)
What if I wish to donate by check?
A: Yes! Please make your check
out to "Mission: Paid Off Letter." 
Our PO BOX is: 

3011 W 183rd StreetUnit 302 
Homewood, IL 60430

story:
Who we are and what we do

The South African Wild Dogs are the first African u23 Ultimate Frisbee team to ever have been assembled! Comparisons have been made between the team and the Avengers or even the Justice League. Nevertheless, even perhaps the greatest team ever assembled needs support, and that's where you come in.
Every great team sport story involves conflict, a struggle to overcome. In this case, rather than a bullying and antagonistic adversary our constant struggle is against the prices of travel costs and the cruel monetary importance of accommodation and food.
As the WFDF 2015 U23 Worlds Ultimate Championship is in London all these costs pile up and really impede our chances of going to the biggest tournament of our lives. To put it plain and simply, We cannot afford the costs. 

What We Need

To be honest, we are almost exclusively students and flat broke. We simply do not have the money to accomplish our dream. That being said, with your contribution we will be covered for our lunches, dinners and accommodation for the entire time that we are in London. As Ultimate is not a Professionally recognised sport it is hard for us to ask for sponsors and get to this amazing experience. In perspective, it will cost each player around $2700 for our baseline costs, not including other smaller costs. What we are asking for is enough for our players to breathe a collective sigh of relief as the burden is lifted considerably by your contribution.

The Impact

100% of your donations will go towards our accommodation/travel/sustenance cost. Each donation, every penny, brings us one step closer to blazing the trail of SA Ultimate competing on a global scale. If you want direct quotes for where your money will go: $30 buys 1 player a meal (London aint cheap!).  $400 ensures one player is entered into the tournament. $500 pays for one players entire accommodation for the entire 8 days.   $1000 pays for lodging for the team for one day. $3000 feeds the team for the whole tournament.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute that's ok! There's another way to help.
Spread the word! We are asking as honestly as we can for you to share this with everyone. Even that Uncle you only see at Christmas. Anyone that would have an inkling of a desire to help us would go a long way.

And that's all there is to it.

story:
SEEDS & Earthwork Music Present: THE QUEST

Help Us Secure a Venue to Put These Kids On Stage!

SEEDS is a nonprofit organization with a 15 year tradition of partnership and arts integration in northwest Michigan. The Earthwork Music Collective believes in the intrinsic power of music to raise community and self-awareness. Together, we are planning a journey - a quest - to reconnect K-12 youth to their own sources of creativity, power and voice. 

What We Need & What You Get!

We need your help to make a public performance in Traverse City on July 2 possible! The costs of facility rental, sound equipment, recording and engineering, staging, student transportation and comp tickets to their parents are very real and will total approximately $10,000. 

In communities facing persistent poverty, opportunities for artistic enrichment and expression are minimal at best. SEEDS provides high-quality instruction throughout the year to K-12 students throughout northwest Michigan.

Qualified instructors from SEEDS, Earthwork Music and Blackbird Arts are providing months of instruction to K-12 youth. This is happening in schools like Kalkaska and Brethren Middle Schools, Mesick and Rapid City Elementary and others right now! 

These youth deserve to present their achievements to a wider audience!

    The Impact

    "I didn't even know that I liked beets!"

    "I used to be shy - painfully shy! Music has helped me find my own voice and given me an outlet to express my feelings. Thank you for The Quest!"

    "Kalkaska Rocks! I love my hometown!"

    By giving now, you will make it possible for us to know that we can pay for the performance costs before the show opens rather than have us bite our nails hoping that we sold enough tickets and refreshments to offset our expenses. Plus you'll get cool perks for being an early adopter!

    Any dollars from this campaign that go beyond our actual costs for this year's performance will be immediately invested in making The Quest 2016 possible! So please consider becoming a significant sponsor!

    Business Sponsorship Opportunities

    Do you think that your business would be interested in sponsoring The Quest? As a corporate sponsor, there are several levels in which your sponsorship will be recognized. Please contact kaitlyn@ ecoseeds.org for more details!

    History of The Quest

    In 2014, The Quest was focused on history and included collaboration with the American Folklife Center, the Library of Congress and Michigan State University's Traditional Arts Program to celebrate the 75th anniversary of Alan Lomax's Michigan folksong recordings. 

    Students visited historical centers and important historical sites. They captured stories from their elders and learned the music of their ancestors. Then, they made it their own, re-crafting old songs with new words, using new tunes for old worlds and learning about their place through song and art.

    Check out this short video about The Quest 2014:

    Learn more at KeepUpTheQuest.com

story:
Who Am I?

Stella Palikarova is currently completing her Masters of Information at the University of Toronto, with a background in Film and Psychology from York University (2007), having graduated summa cum laude. Her academic interests have always related to the intersecting experiences of disability, from her undergraduate thesis on the dating experiences of adolescent girls with congenital, physical disabilities, to her current thesis work on the ethical implications of cybernetic implants for people with disabilities. For the latter, Stella received a Masters SSHRC. Stella is a frequent guest speaker on subjects pertaining to disability and continues to pursue filmmaking and creative writing.

Stella and Andrew Morrison-Gurza are co-directors of "Deliciously Disabled," a disability awareness consulting company that strives to bring the lived experiences of people with disabilities into pop culture. Our motto is "making disability accessible". 

What Is Needed 

Together with Fran Odette, educator and advocate with a focus on issues faced by women with disabilities, the three of us have been accepted to present 

The Art of the “Hook-Up” When You’re Hot and Disabled at this year's "Playground, 2015" conference at the Holiday Inn in Toronto. This frank, possibly risqué, discussion covers  all of your most burning questions about how to "hook-up" safely and enjoyably with able-bodied folk when you have a physical disability, in an age of online dating, persisting ablism, and physical barriers.

As an indie, non-for profit conference, the organizers of "Playground" are observing the costs of the conference and their is no funding left over to accommodate access needs. In order to be able to attend and present this year, I will need:

  • Roughly $300 to cover caregiver expenses for three days
  • Roughly another $650 to cover accessible hotel accommodation for 2 nights (turns out that the Holiday Inn does not have a wheelchair accessible room two beds, so I will have to book an additional room for my PSW) 

The Impact

"Playground" facilitates: Workshops. Conversations. Discovery. A sex-positive, inclusive, & intersectional sexuality event.  

This conference provides a space for people from all walks of life to come and share their knowledge and experiences with you. Without the support of generous donors, people with physical impairments like myself would not be able to come out to this conference and held to further facilitate more inclusive, sex positive social spaces, free of physical and attitudinal barriers. Your contribution will make it possible for me to continue doing valuable work in education, activism, and promotion in this area.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Help by distributing my campaign through your social networks!

story:
JM Senior Class Party

Each year, the parents of graduating Seniors from John Marshall High School create a Senior Class Party to help our graduates celebrate in a safe environment.  Our party is held at the high school and features many activities  and prizes for participants.  Although each year's planning is a surprise, in the past, activities have including a hypnotist, prizes, henna, bounce houses and more!


This year, we need your help to support our Seniors as they transition from high school into the world.  If each family donated $10 toward the Senior Party, we could raise our goal of $3,000 in private contributions toward our total goal of $15,000 in fundraising!

What we need

We know that many of our parents and families of our graduating Seniors hold down full time jobs, care for other children and often volunteer extensively in the community.  We have created this campaign so that you can help without ever leaving your house! 

100% of your tax deductible donation will go directly toward the cost of producing this event!


Our goal of $3,000 from private donations is only part of our overall fundraising planning, coordinated this year by professional fundraiser and member of the planning committee, Terri Allred.  Our comprehensive fundraising plan includes a wine tasting and silent auction, ROCKchester concert, Corporate Sponsorship, and more!

Please give generously and share our campaign with your family and friends!

story:
Family and Friends,

I am delighted to finish my undergrad career this year and I have your support to thank. I feel blessed to have such a strong support group to keeping me motivated in my pursuit of my dreams. When I entered UC Merced, I created two personal goals that I would accomplish by the time my undergraduate career would come to end. One was to make a difference and leave my mark on the school, and the other was to study a semester abroad. I have accomplished the first one by being a Resident Assistant to over 200 students, helping to guide them in their transition into college and being their ultimate resource. My second goal, I will accomplish by studying a semester abroad at the UC Center London in Great Britain. By going abroad UC Center London will provide me with the unique opportunity to study British and EU politics in conjunction with interning with a premiere London establishment. By studying abroad, I will be able to effectively network on the international level allowing me to broaden my horizons personally, academically, and professionally.

(Recipient of the Ruiz Prize in Entrepreneurial Communications at UC Merced's Pitch Fest 2014)

Who am I?

To summarize myself briefly I am a Southern California, first-generation student at University of California Merced. I am currently majoring in Management and minoring in Political Science with an emphasis on International Relations with the intent on earning my Masters in Business Administration. My ultimate goal is to break the gender barriers of the business world in Marketing and Communications and to continue my involvement in academia, leadership and mentor-ship.

During my tenure at UC Merced I have been able to gain experience with developing creative processes, and managing events. My project management skills have allowed me to successfully organize and execute fun, engaging, and educational events for nearly 200 students. The results of these events have led to more community involvement and education about pertinent issues. As a Resident Assistant I was able to learn how to better empathize with others to motivate them to take action to improve their roommate situations or help them become more successful. I was successfully able to transfer this knowledge to my participation in UC Merced's Annual Entrepreneurial Pitch Fest. After presenting a unique business concept to a panel of entrepreneurs and CEO's of Start-up companies, I was able to convince them of the efficacy of the concept I presented and was named a finalist of the competition.

Additionally I have served multiple internships including Energy Service Corps where I was responsible for obtaining media coverage for ESC’s work in educating Merced County about the Green Initiative. Within this internship I worked with leading broadcasting companies in Merced County and worked as UCM's Young Democrat's media consultant for the 2012 guest speaker, American Political Activist Ralph Nader. 


(Energy Service Corps Internship 2012-2013 Media Relations Coordinator)

(Housing and Residence Life Student Staff 2013-2014)

My Goal for this Campaign

I want to raise $2,500.00 to help finance my upcoming study abroad experience in London, England. I will be studying in London for the academic semester (from August 2015 to December 2015) at the University of California Center London via the University of California Education Abroad Program (UCEAP). I also want to be the example for future students that want to study abroad but face many constraints that are preventing them from doing so, such as finance issues, not being informed, not believing it’s possible, not knowing how to go forth upon this, etc.

(ACCENT Study Center, UC Center London aka My home abroad!)


My Story

I am the product of a hardworking and loving family. Both my mother and father stressed the importance of higher education in my childhood. Together they taught me determination, integrity and that will a little bit of elbow grease, I could conquer anything. Gone, but not forgotten I wake each day to the memory of my father who passed away in 2006. Both he and my mother dreamed of a bright future for me and I have them as well as the love and support from my Fraternal Grandparents Penny Behnke, Chuck Dorothy, Glen Behnke and Beverly Hawkins, as well as my Step-Father Brian to thank for getting me this far. My pursuits could not have been possible without them as well as my South Dakota and California family.

I am the eldest of four siblings who mean the world to me. Though they are young, I like to take the role of big sister beyond just an age gap by being a role model for their future pursuits. As a first-generation University student I hope to encourage a path for them to follow and to expose them directly to the wonders of what higher education has provided me and will continue to provide me for the rest of my life.

Coming from a mid-size town in Southern California, my horizons were expanded when my family was able to host a foreign exchange student for a semester. This ultimately led to me leaving the county for the first time and travelling to France to visit her. Every day spent abroad tickled my thirst to further explore the world and to obtain a greater understanding of different cultures. I knew that someday my next big adventure would take me from the banks of the Siene to the River Thames. I knew that my next international destination needed to be the United Kingdom.



Why Do I Want to Study Abroad and Why Did I Choose London?


Currently studying as a Management major with a Political Science minor, UC Center London will provide me with the unique opportunity to study British and EU politics in conjunction with the possibility of gaining international work experience. As a Senior, I need one more class to complete my upper division Political Sciences minor. The class from the UC Center in London that will fulfill this requirement is Britain and European Union. I feel that learning about the dynamic relationship about these two governing bodies would be the perfect capstone to my minor degree that has been largely based on an International Relations emphasis. I am also enrolling in the Internship Workforce course which would allow me to intern for a premiere London establishment. I have not had a lot of experience working outside of an academic setting, so this course will be greatly beneficial for me. Not  gain professional experience that would help launch my career, but I would also be able to reaffirm what I am learning during the internship. Working in a unique environment will aid in a first-hand application of my management major.  By studying abroad, I will be able to effectively network on the international level allowing me to broaden my horizons personally, academically, and professionally. 

I have always appreciated British culture, literature, customs and rich history. Having grown up during the height of JK Rowling's fame through the Harry Potter series, and the regeneration of the classic Doctor Who Sci-Fi television series, I have always been entranced by British pop-culture. Additionally as a political science minor I am intrigued by the success of Western Society's longest running monarchy. It amazes me that this tradition and form of government has been able to adapt and withstand modern pressures with poise.


What I Need

Here is a brief overview of how much my program is going to cost, how much financial aid I am receiving, the amount of money I won through scholarships, and how much I will have to pay out of pocket:

UCEAP Costs – 2015 (Costs):                                                         $16,266.00
Financial Aid:                                                                                                 - $3,750.00
Scholarships:                                                                                                - $10,439.00                        ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Total Out-of-Pocket Costs:                                                                    =  $  2,077.00

Right now, I need $2,077 to cover my remaining costs for me to study abroad in London for the semester.  I am currently asking for $2,500 not only to cover the remaining balance but I would use the extra funds for food, books, and other remaining living expenses for England.

Honestly, the donation you give me means so much more than the actual dollar amount. By you donating, even if it’s $1, you are telling me that you believe in me and my goals. That, there, means so much more than any dollar amount. Having a group of people, even if it’s just one person, say, “Hey, Kaylin, I believe in you and what you want to do in life, and I’m willing to help in any way I can,” is something priceless. I know my experiences will be memorable, amazing, and will be an invaluable experience that will help me grow both professionally and personally.


Other Ways You Can Help

Any way you can contribute in your own way will be greatly appreciated.

If you can’t contribute/donate any money towards my campaign, don’t worry about it! I completely understand. If you’re still interested in helping, though, please spread the word! Tell your friends, family or colleagues about my campaign! I would also appreciate it if you would share my campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Google+, or whatever social media you may use.

If you have read any of this campaign, shared it, donated, and or contributed in some way, thank you so much. I really appreciate you for taking the time to do this for me. Whomever you may be—family, friend, friend of a friend, former classmate, mentor, acquaintance—I sincerely thank you for helping me be that much closer to reaching my goals and dreams. I will update this campaign as I progress through my time in London and keep you updated, even after the campaign has closed. Words cannot express the gratitude I have for you and everyone.

Love Always,

Kaylin-Marie

the example for future students that want to study abroad but face many
constraints that are preventing them from doing so, such as finance issues, not
being informed, not believing it’s possible, not knowing how to go forth upon
this, etc.

(ACCENT Study Center, UC Center London aka My home abroad!)


My Story




I am the product of a hardworking and loving family. Both my mother and father stressed the importance of higher education in my childhood. Together they taught me determination, integrity and that will a little bit of elbow grease, I could conquer anything. Gone, but not forgotten I wake each day to the memory of my father who passed away in 2006. Both he and my mother dreamed of a bright future for me and I have them as well as the love and support from my Fraternal Grandparents Penny Behnke, Chuck Dorothy, Glen Behnke and Beverly Hawkins, as well as my Step-Father Brian to thank for getting me this far. My pursuits could not have been possible without them as well as my South Dakota and California family.
I am the eldest of four siblings who mean the world to me. Though they are young, I like to take the role of big sister beyond just an age gap by being a role model for their future pursuits. As a first-generation University student I hope to encourage a path for them to follow and to expose them directly to the wonders of what higher education has provided me and will continue to provide me for the rest of my life.
Coming from a mid-size town in Southern California, my horizons were expanded when my
family was able to host a foreign exchange student for a semester. This
ultimately led to me leaving the county for the first time and travelling to
France to visit her. Every day spent abroad tickled my thirst to further
explore the world and to obtain a greater understanding of different cultures.
I knew that someday my next big adventure would take me from the banks of the
Siene to the River Thames. I knew that my next international destination needed
to be the United Kingdom.




Why Do I Want to Study
Abroad and Why Did I Choose London?



Currently studying as
a Management major with a Political Science minor, UC Center London will
provide me with the unique opportunity to study British and EU politics in
conjunction with the possibility of gaining international work experience. As a
Senior, I need one more class to complete my upper division Political Sciences
minor. The class from the UC Center in London that will fulfill this
requirement is Britain and European Union. I feel that learning
about the dynamic relationship about these two governing bodies would be the
perfect capstone to my minor degree that has been largely based on an International
Relations emphasis. I am also enrolling in the Internship
Workforce course which would allow me to intern for a premiere London
establishment. I have not had a lot of experience working outside of an
academic setting, so this course will be greatly beneficial for me. Not  gain professional experience that would help launch my career,
but I would also be able to reaffirm what I am learning during the internship.
Working in a unique environment will aid in a first-hand application of my
management major.  By studying abroad, I
will be able to effectively network on the international level allowing me to
broaden my horizons personally, academically, and professionally.  
I have always
appreciated British culture, literature, customs and rich history. Having grown
up during the height of JK Rowling's fame through the Harry Potter series, and
the regeneration of the classic Doctor Who Sci-Fi television series, I have
always been entranced by British pop-culture. Additionally as a political
science minor I am intrigued by the success of Western Society's longest
running monarchy. It amazes me that this tradition and form of government has
been able to adapt and withstand modern pressures with poise.

What I Need
Here is a brief
overview of how much my program is going to cost, how much financial aid I am
receiving, the amount of money I won through scholarships, and how much I will
have to pay out of pocket:
UCEAP Costs – 2015 (Costs):                                                         $16,266.00
Financial Aid:     
                     
                     
                       
                     
 - $3,750.00
Scholarships:               
                     
                     
                     
              - $10,439.00                        ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Total Out-of-Pocket Costs:             
                     
                     
          =  $  2,077.00

Right now, I need $2,077 to cover my remaining costs for
me to study abroad in London for the semester.  I am currently asking for $2,500 not only to
cover the remaining balance but I would use the extra funds for food, books,
and other remaining living expenses for England.
Honestly, the donation
you give me means so much more than the actual dollar amount. By you donating,
even if it’s $1, you are telling me that you believe in me and my
goals. That, there, means so much more than any dollar amount. Having a group
of people, even if it’s just one person, say, “Hey, Kaylin, I believe in you
and what you want to do in life, and I’m willing to help in any way I can,” is
something priceless. I know my experiences will be memorable, amazing,
and will be an invaluable experience that will help me grow both professionally
and personally.

Other Ways You Can
Help
Any way you can
contribute in your own way will be greatly appreciated.
If you can’t
contribute/donate any money towards my campaign, don’t worry about it! I
completely understand. If you’re still interested in helping, though, please
spread the word! Tell your friends, family or colleagues about my campaign! I would also appreciate it if you would share my
campaign on Facebook, Twitter, Instagram, Google+, or whatever social media you may use.
If you have read any
of this campaign, shared it, donated, and or contributed in some way, thank you
so much. I really appreciate you for taking the time to do this for me.
Whomever you may be—family, friend, friend of a friend, former classmate, mentor, acquaintance—I sincerely
thank you for helping me be that much closer to reaching my goals and dreams. I
will update this campaign as I progress through my time in London and keep you
updated, even after the campaign has closed. Words cannot express the gratitude
I have for you and everyone. 
Love Always,
Kaylin-Marie

story:
GIVING A VOICE TO SPANISH SPEAKERS IN POLITICS 

Who We Are

Nuestros Politicos (nuestrospoliticos.com) is a social media platform that connects the Spanish-speaking community to their political environment. Our idea began with a simple realization: While there is a wealth of Spanish entertainment available online, there are few places that provide a platform for sharing political opinions news that are important to Spanish-speakers. We are a small team of entrepreneurs who want to change that. We are placing a spotlight on the important trends in politics!

Context: Spanish-speakers form one of the largest global communities. There are more than 450 million Spanish Speakers around the world. We are young. Technically savvy. Online and connected. But unemployment rate among Spanish-speakers is high. The borders of many of our communities do not include the best schools, proper environmental standards, funding for new businesses, but do include a labyrinth of red tape...it is a daily challenge to get ahead. We need innovative ways to let our leaders know about our issues and start tackling them seriously.  That’s where nuestrospoliticos.com comes in. 

See How NP is Giving a Voice to Spanish Speakers

So how are we making an impact? Ideas on our site come from diverse backgrounds around the world. Our users contribute their own content, sharing their ideas with each other, with our staff, and with the global community on matters including immigration, important elections, higher education, the need for better public transit, economic development, and foreign policy. 

Below are some snapshots from our platform:

TU VOZ - Your Voice. Here users post and share their ideas with each other.

COSAS QUE FUNCIONAN - Things That Work. Here we spotlight the positive political developments that are taking place. 


Why We Need YOU

Breaking ground in political news has never been done this way before where we combine elements of news content and social media. Users can get coverage on political events in our news center and then express their opinions via articles, comments, and likes.

Scaling our platform and reaching the global Spanish-speaking audience will take more resources. Our full operational cost is $79k/year. We are facing an immediate funding gap. If we can raise $50k, we will be able to operate at full capacity for the rest of 2015.

Our community is full of youth trying to expand their horizons, get engaged in their political system, and express their visions & ideas. We need partners like you - people who believe in the positive power of community and public service.

A view of what we'll be able to accomplish with additional funds:


How Else Can I Help?

Most importantly, give whatever you can to the campaign. Many small donations will add up and make it possible for Nuestros Politicos to give Spanish speakers a stronger voice!

In addition to that, help us grow this grassroots movement by doing the following:

  • Register as a user on our site: If you love our campaign, register at nuestrospoliticos.com. And invite your friends!
  • Stay connected: Follow Nuestros Politicos on Facebook and NPoliticos on Twitter, then share our top updates with your friends.
  • Spread the word: Share #npoliticos on Facebook and Twitter, or tell your friends in an email.
  • Post our logo: If you love our campaign, post our logo on your social media networks.

 

Thank you :)

story:
In A Nutshell

If at the end of a run, a bike ride, a hike you ever found yourself thinking how great it felt and yet, wondering how this instinctively good feeling, that sports provides, could also make the world a better place: read on.

We are Athletic Elevator, a charity* start-up aiming at improving the sports movement where we see most potential for growth. We operate in Guyana, a beautiful Caribbean country, on the northern coast of South America. We believe sports and education together can, indeed, make the world a better place, and we think we have the recipe to turn this belief into practice.

We are raising an initial round of GBP 10,000 that will fund the first year of a broad scholarship scheme for Guyanese student-athletes to get them ready to attend college in the USA. We need USD 1,000 for 10 students in their third to last year of high school, for the school year 2015/16.

In the following years, we’ll raise more funds to keep sustaining each existing scholarship for 2 further years until graduation, and set up the same scheme for new classes. That means a total of USD 30,000 to be raised annually when the scheme is fully functional. But we want to hit the ground running and have a professional setup before we go hit the potential bigger sources of funding. Our story wants to be one of doing, not just talking. Hope is a powerful force, but hope channelled into a concrete way forward is even more powerful. That’s why the first thing we want to do is start the scholarship scheme. This year. At the start of school in September 2015. You can be the beginning of a big thing!

A few words about myself and why I need your support: I am a long distance runner by passion, an energy expert by profession and a global gypsy by inclination. Running has been my second skin for 20 years, and Athletic Elevator is my way of giving back to the sport. Think of this crowdfunding as a kick-off to a much broader project.

*Not a proper charity yet. It takes money to set one up. We aim at registering a charity in the UK and a 501(c)(3) organization in the US. That’s one of the things we’ll do with the initial funding.


What We Do With Your Money

The initial GBP 10,000 will hit our three shortest term targets:

  • Fund the first year of scholarships (USD 10,000 = around GBP 7,000)

  • Create media visibility for the Guyana Olympic Association through targeted actions such as the creation and improvement of the olympic.gy website and related social media pages (GBP 1,000)

  • Set up a registered charity organization in the UK and a non-profit under 501(c)(3) in the US (GBP 1,000)

  • Crowdfunding fees and perks (GBP 1,000)

This is just the seeds of what’s cooking at Athletic Elevator. The project as a whole has three goals: supporting the athletes of today, growing those of tomorrow (through initiatives such as the scholarships), and help the Guyanese sports movement grow and be known abroad:

  • Support the athletes of today, whom we already have! Guyana does not use “participation” wild card places in order to appear at championships. We have a 40-strong representation out in Toronto this summer for the Pan American Games. We send athletes to the Olympic Games, who qualify through the difficult international IAAF standards. But we don’t have a sponsor. It shouldn’t be difficult to find a technical sponsor.

  • Grow the athletes of tomorrow. This is where your funding goes! Every year there will be 10 new scholarships, with a duration of 3 years, aimed at growing high school kids into the athletes and students they need to become in order to qualify for a free US student-athlete college education. Through an extensive network we will then get them recruited in college. And change their lives.



  • Promote the sports movement in Guyana and its visibility abroad, through constant collaboration with the Guyana Olympic Association, to which we are advisors. With part of this crowdfunding, we are setting up websites and media visibility for the GOA. This sounds like a corn ball thing but it’s actually quite key – we want to show to the world that Guyana is a fertile and legitimate place to invest their money, efforts, thoughts and hopes.



What's In It For You!

There’s more to it... we have great perks for your contributions too! Sure, as a charity project the most important perk will be to see your funded athletes grow into the Olympians of tomorrow – the 2015/16 class will be 20 years old in 2020, which is prime time for a sprinter to run fast: what a story would it be if some of those 10 kids end up qualifying for the Tokyo Olympics! Anyway, look at the perks list, we also have more short-term ways to say thank you!

Let me also make one important disclosure, which has to do with the return on your investment in us. We are sure your generosity will help us fully reach our goal. But it wouldn’t be respectful towards you, our supporters, if were not prepared to the possibility that we may fall short. In the spirit of full transparency we want to let you know exactly what we will do if that’s the case:

  • The scholarships will be prioritised, so anything raised up to USD 10,000 (roughly GBP 7,000) will be channelled into those; we would rather have to cut on our admin costs (see “other ways you can help” below on how you can actually help us cut those costs) than to curtail our core goal of giving out 10 scholarships in September.

  • In the (unhappy) event that we won’t reach even the scholarships amount, we will still launch 10 scholarships but of a reduced amount. USD 1,000/year go quite a long way in Guyana, and so would USD 800, or 700. Still, we very much hope it will be US 1,000. But at least now you know what’s in our minds in that eventuality.


Other Ways You Can Help

Alright, we understand that you may like the cause but may not be ready to commit some of your $$$ to it. The good news is, there are other ways you can help us out just as much. Please get in touch at info@athleticelevator.org if any of the below applies:


Traditional ways

  • We used our networks to spread the word about AE’s fundraising. Share with your friends! Indiegogo has a useful “share” tool which you can use to post on your Twitter and Facebook.

  • On July 29th, there will be a Thunderclap! Which means we'll try to reach much further than our network of contacts through a Facebook app that lets us post a promotional pitch for this campaign on your wall. Please register to it and let us use your network to spread the word! Use this link: http://thndr.it/1Kb3IgO (We can only post a one-off message. Thunderclap won't spam. It's a serious service. It's legit. And it works!)

  • We’d love to hear your ideas! This is very much a blank canvas project. We shrank our brains to the fullest, they are rather empty and we’d love some more input.

  • The above includes any criticism you may want to direct to us.


Less traditional but perhaps more intriguing ways

  • We need legal advice. If you are a tax accountant or a lawyer or are simply knowledgeable about charity stuff, and would like to help us pro bono in setting up a charity organization either in the UK or in the US, pro bono, please get in touch as we’re looking for you.

  • We need media savvy support. If you are into social media campaigns, or digital marketing, consider this campaign of ours. It is nice but admittedly we could do much more if we only had more experience and expertise. Help!

  • We are looking for technical sponsors for Guyana. If you are into sports marketing and/or athletes management, and have ideas as to how we can structure one or more technical sponsorships, the Guyana Olympic Association is looking for partners. These can be delegation-wide or specific to disciplines; they can be related to the “athletes of today” or we could build a story and partnership with AE to support the athletes of tomorrow (e.g. the funded students need kit!).

  • We want to figure out a way to exploit the untapped tourism potential of Guyana combined with the fact that Georgetown now has state-of-the-art sports facilities. If you organize sports tours or vacation packages, do get in touch and we’ll have an extended chat on this! It is really easy to fly to G’town from both North America (direct flights from JFK and Montreal) and the UK (British Airways flies direct to Trinidad, which is a short flight away).


The Long Story

I figure some of you might be curious to get a clearer picture on how this whole Athletic Elevator thing was possibly conceived. So if you have time and feel ready to steer towards the philosophical edge of this adventure, let me tell you more about the story that led us here.

As I said, I am a long distance runner by passion, an energy expert by profession and a global gypsy by inclination. In prose, this means that I have a career in energy consulting which led me to travel the globe. I am currently in transit between London, which has been my base for the best part of the last 10 years, and Colorado where I am about to take on a new professional adventure. Over these years I also spent shorter periods for assignments in Washington DC, Brussels, New York and Houston. For work or simple curiosity, without an actual plan, I ended up spending time in all continents except Antarctica. Global gypsy enough? OK. As to running: it has been my second skin for 20 years, and of the big passions of my life it has been the most elusive; that is, the one I always was unconditionally in love with, but which I always felt guilty for not prioritizing enough. This is because I believe in the role of sport as a metaphor of life, and an enabler for philosophical understanding and education. As such, it has to be an amateur activity, a side gig, which is why I never pursued the professional athlete route. At the same time, as work responsibilities and pressure stacked up, I grew afraid that all this running around in circles on a track and on the roads was only wasting my time and doing no good to the world. How exactly would the world become a better place if I clocked 2h15 instead of 2h19 in the marathon? Would anyone’s life get any better if I did? Who else would benefit, besides my own vanity?

But then something happened. The sort of stuff that makes people say: things fall into place. Actually, I am a sturdy rational thinker and don’t quite believe they do so without receiving the correct incentives. You’ve got to work very hard to beat cosmic entropy, you have to search deep, you have no assurances of success and you have to accept that the efficiency of your efforts is less, much less than 100%. In other words to catch the right train, even though you don’t know if it will ever come, you have to at least be waiting for it on the platform. The train I wanted to catch was something that would make sense of this restlessness, this feeling that I had a puzzle of a life which could somehow become a beautiful figure but I didn’t know how. After all I spent 35 years hearing people tell me that the intellectual and physical dimensions of life are irredeemably separate things, and although my own experience hinted that it might not be such a clear-cut story, who was I to challenge such a widespread view?

Another complicating factor was that I was kind of good at what I was doing, but nowhere near good enough for the global competition I had thrown myself in. As one of many not so talented runners, the solution was not to be sought in the improvement of my mediocre standard. I looked up at the likes of Wesley Korir – I know, you haven’t heard this name before; when you live at the margins of conventional life, you also end up worshipping unsung heroes – and I realised that winning the Boston Marathon and then moving back to my home country, running for parliament and changing it for the better was not really in the cards. If I had a chance, I had to seek it in the mixture of unique experience that I had. Those strange puzzle tiles, part of which I had been given, part of which I had built. I had to blend things. Play my best hand. Sports. Management. A cosmopolitan approach to life.

When you have these sorts of thoughts, and you are the sort of guy that I am, you end up browsing Google Maps late at night, asking yourself “What good amid these? O me! O life!”. There must be a place in the world where even with my limited means, I can make a difference. What sort of place does it have to be?

It has to be a place where I can show up and say, here, now, that I have something good to offer. At the same time it has to be a place where what’s on offer has to get traction, there has to be a sensibility to sports and there has to be a fertile ground for the importance of education in improving one’s life conditions. It took a while of searching. I was perhaps making mistakes in my approach. I was getting nowhere. But the best thing about making mistakes is that you perceive a learning curve. Let me tell you a dirty secret about exploring outside one’s comfort zone: the sheer perception of a learning curve has its own lifting force. It seems very weak, an uninviting whirlwind, but if you rely on it, it can keep you in the air for a while, while you try to set up a more stable lift. And when it comes to the feeling of getting nowhere and being exhausted and the finish line not in sight, that’s a marathon runner’s bread and butter: around mile 20, it always feels like that. If you don’t have a “shit, another 6 to go” moment around mile 20, all it means is you haven’t pushed hard enough. You can address it in one of two ways: either you quit, or you shut your demons off and keep going. If you manage the latter, you find strength you didn’t know existed, you trick your body into getting through another 3 miles, then you push hard with all your mental power through another 2, then you crawl the final mile, and in the end guess what: the finish line appears.

So, exactly according to schedule, after getting nowhere for long enough, Guyana appeared on the horizon. A small country, where an individual could make a macroscopic difference to a population. An English speaking place, which was paramount to the concept I had in mind (more on this below). A place where education is held in high respect and actually with a high school attendance rate of over 60%. And perhaps most importantly for my own story, an Olympic Association which showed interest in my propositions.

After the unbound nature of my mindset led me to scout as far as the tropical rainforest of South America, I said to myself, enough for the cosmopolitan side. Now how could I blend the remaining skills – sports experience and management expertise?

Two ideas came out. The first was to help the athletes of today. Guyana is not one of those small nations who use quota places in order to appear at championships. There are sprinters out there who are capable of low 10” in the 100m and 45” in the 400m; depending on how much you are into track & field, this will seem to you between awesome and outright impressive – especially considering that the first ever proper track in Guyana was inaugurated this April. More remarkably still, Aliann Pompey won a Commonwealth Games (another one under the chapter of unsung heroes. Look her up on Wiki). And there is a 40-strong representation out in Toronto as we speak, for the Pan American Games. Guyana regularly sends sprinters to the World and Olympic Games who qualify through the difficult international IAAF standards. But they don’t have a sponsor. It shouldn’t be difficult to find them a technical sponsor. This was the first idea.

The second idea is the one we’re crowdfunding for right now. It is also more in line with the philosophy of my approach to sports. As I said, I am in sports as a metaphoric journey to a better understanding of life; sports as an enabler to our truest nature. This is how the “athletes of tomorrow” branch of the project was conceived. Small digression: my wife has just finished a degree in the US, as a foreign student-athlete, fully funded by the track&field team to compete in the collegiate NCAA sports system. She had to train hard and she had to study hard and those were tough years, but as a result, not only did she slash her 5000m time by almost half a minute, but she was also able to earn a US degree for free (and, for US readers who will be sensitive to the topic, no student loans to repay). From here, the step was short: what if we could grow a batch of Guyanese kids, during their high school years, so that they reach their final year, which is the one when they can be recruited for college, and they have an academic track record as well as sports performance level that they can qualify for NCAA competition? And then we put them in touch with US college coaches, who are in constant search for new athletes to fill their rosters with?

Wow, this looks like one big window of opportunity. This is also when Athletic Elevator was properly born. With the help of a few friends, as well as the support of the Guyana Olympic Association, we structured this project.

And in the end... What good amid these, O me! O Life!

“Answer: That the powerful play goes on, and you may contribute a verse.”

This is the first verse.

Let’s make it a poem. A beautiful one.
