story:
Who We Are

All Wheels Up is the only organization working to crash test wheelchairs for commercial flight so people who use Wheelchairs can fly from the safety of their chairs.

We were created in 2011 by a Mother determined to help her Son with Spinal Muscular Atrophy be able to travel after experiencing how difficult it is to travel by plane with a Son who uses a Wheelchair. Our team came together from our own experiences and determination trying to fly and we have been working nonstop to help everybody who uses Wheelchairs one day be able to travel from the safety of their Wheelchairs to all the amazing places of the world.

There are 4 million people in the United States (according to the latest Census), 5 million people in Europe, and millions more around the world who use wheelchairs and having Accessible Planes would mean incredible freedom for them and their families.

After researching the entire Air Travel Industry, Regulations, and Process of Flying with an Electric Wheelchair for the last few years, we know it is possible for people who use Wheelchairs to fly on Airplanes from the safety of their chairs with existing technology and hope to show proof of concept to the Airlines, FAA, and Airplane Manufacturers that it can be done.

This will help everyone involved in Air Travel- it will allow the Airlines to reach into a massive untapped market of millions of customers who never fly, save them millions in Wheelchair Repairs they pay each year, save valuable labor for the baggage handlers, create billions for the Airlines, Travel Industry, Tourism Industry, and Hotel Industry, and give individuals who use wheelchairs and their families freedom to travel anywhere in the world.

People with Disabilities in the United States spend an estimated $15 billion annually on travel. You can read more stats here.

What We Are Raising Money For

We are looking to fundraise $15,000 for one day of Wheelchair Crash Tests with Calspan which is an FAA approved aerospace crash test facility. With the data collected in these crash tests, the government data we have secured from other crash tests done on wheelchairs for buses and automobiles, and FAA regulations, we will create a Wheelchair Crash Test Model.

This will also cover the cost of travel for one member of our organization to the facility to document and witness the testing

We have already received generous equipment donations for the Crash Test from such companies as Q’straint which is the world leader in Wheelchair Restraints, Intellectual data donated by SEA industries, and others donations.

What we hope to achieve with this project is proof of concept that wheelchairs can withstand the FAA Crash Test of 16 G – just as they have already passed for crash tests in vehicles. 

We will give data to the FAA, Congress, Airlines, Airplane Manufacturers, Universities specializing in Aviation Testing, and organizations specializing in Wheelchair Safety. 

We hope the FAA and Congress will release funding for more in depth research with organizations such as the FAA and Rehabilitation Engineering and Assistive Technology Society of North America (RESNA), The National Institute on Disability and Rehabilitation Research (NIDRR), and the Rehabilitation Engineering Research Center on Wheelchair Transportation Safety (RERC WTS).

We also hope to work directly with Airplane Manufacturers such as Airbus and Boeing and Airplane Interior Manufacturers such as B/E Aerospace.

We hope this campaign will get us to our goal and help us get one step closer to people who use Wheelchairs being able to fly on Airplanes from the safety of their chairs. We are a 501c3 Nonprofit so all donations are Tax Deductible.

Long Term Goal

Individuals who use Wheelchairs can ride Trains, Boats, Subways, Buses, Cars, and even Ride Sharing from the safety of their chairs right now, but not Airplanes.

Right now, flying with a Wheelchair is a nightmare especially if someone has a neuromuscular disease severely diminishing their strength. They have to get out of their wheelchair, which literally is their legs, at the gate and transfer into an aisle chair to get on to the plane before transferring one more time into the airplane seat. They have to sit for the entire flight without the medically necessary back supports, cushion, safety restraints, foot plates, breathing equipment, or feeding equipment their wheelchair might have. Some of them even have to be held upright during takeoff and landings if they do not have the strength.

When they finally arrive at the destination, they have to worry about if their wheelchair gets damaged and, more often than not, it does get damaged even if they have done everything to protect it such as taking off the headrest and joystick at the gate. We have heard from people of their wheelchairs getting completely broken and even sent to the wrong airport if you can believe it. This hurts the airlines as well because they have to pay millions in repairs every year.

We have many images of flying with a wheelchair on our Image Gallery and Facebook and Twitter pages.


Ironically the other parts of flying for someone who uses a Wheelchair are not a problem and there are advancements like Accessible Bathrooms rapidly approaching. You can also rent Accessible Vans and get Accessible Hotel Rooms all around the world.

How Else You Can Help

  • Please follow us on Facebook and Twitter. We will be doing much more in the future such as reaching out to Congress, FAA, Airplane Manufacturers, and the Airlines and we will need YOUR help.
  • Tell your friends and families about our campaign, organization, and what we are fighting for.

We hope to make the dream of flying from the safety of Wheelchairs into a reality for all individuals who use them and their families. There are so many amazing places around the world and a wheelchair should not stop you from traveling to them.

story:
Help Ethiopian Israeli Kids go to Summer Camp

Across Israel in August, schools and subsidized programs are shut down.  Parents with means will pay to send their kids to daycare and summer camps.  But nearly half of all Ethiopian Israeli kids CANNOT AFFORD to go to these programs!  Almost half live on or below the poverty line.  Parents must work, often at two jobs, so in the summer, for most Ethiopian Israeli kids, it's boredom, missed opportunities or worse - they end up wandering the streets, vulnerable to whatever may happen.

Friends by Nature-Community Empowerment offers an alternative:  

SPONSOR AN ETHIOPIAN ISRAELI CHILD TO GO TO CAMP!!!  

In four Israeli cities -  Gedera, Rishon LeZion, Beit Shemesh, and Petach Tikva - Friends by Nature-Community Empowerment (FBN) runs summer camps for children ages 9 - 12, mainly Ethiopian Israeli kids from poor neighborhoods.   With your support, FBN can enable 200 Ethiopian Israeli kids to go to camp, along with hiring 20 Ethiopian Israeli counselors.   The cost is $150 per child.

SEND A KID TO CAMP for $150

For one child for a week:    $150 
(includes activities like arts and crafts, field cooking, outdoor  games, rope climbing, field trip and hikes, AND safety classes in good street habits, safe places to play in their neighborhoods long after camp is over, and  access to after-school programs during the school year)

For one child for two weeks: $280
(less as registration is done only once; materials can last two weeks)

For 50 children/one town for one week:    $7,500 per week
(Choose Gedera, Peta Tikvah, Beit Shemesh or Rishon L'Zion )

We need 200 sponsors for 200 kids.   Please sponsor a child for $150.  


If you are not able to sponsor a child, consider the following donations:

$36 will fund materials for arts & crafts materials for a day for all kids.

$50 will fund rope classes and climbing for a day.

$75 will fund lunch for one day for all.

$100 will fund buses for a one-day field trip to historical sites for one camp.

Camp's impact on kids continues even when it is over:

During camp, kids are taught safety in their neighborhoods - where to play, where not to, where to find help and how to be safe.  And their camp counselors, who live in the neighborhood, are around as volunteers when camp is over to provide a continuing place to turn if necessary.


Who is Friends by Nature (FBN)? 

Friends by Nature is an Israeli NGO dedicated to providing the often-marginalized Ethiopian-Israeli population with community-empowerment programs. The organization runs activities, events, groups, and programs that provide opportunities ranging from leadership training for at-risk youth and at-home tutoring for children, to health and cooking classes, community gardening, and career placement for adults. The founders of Friends by Nature represent a diverse mix of Israelis, both Ethiopian and non-Ethiopian, religious and secular, all committed to and sharing the vision that the success of all immigrant communities within Israel is dependent on a strong sense of identity, community and opportunities.    FBN programs make a difference!

Friends by Nature (FBN) is sponsored by Friends of Ethiopian Jews, Inc..,
a 501(c)(3) nonprofit organization serving as fiscal sponsor to FBN in the
United States.   Friends of Ethiopian Jews, Inc. takes no administrative fees from donations designated for the FBN Summer Camp Program.

story:
Short Summary

Living Positive Mlolongo (LPM) is a Community-Based Organiztion which strives to support the lives of HIV positive families from the slums of Mlolongo in Nairobi Kenya. The organization provides health care, education, income generating programs, rehabilitation and counselling services to women and families. The organization also empowers them for independence and self-sustainability. 

Several years ago I traveled to Kenya to volunteer with LPM. I've seen some of the amazing things they have done within the community and even sponsored a wonderful 10 year old girl who has blossomed in the last several years through the support of sponsorship. This girl came from a home of poverty and abuse and is now safely learning at school where she has safe shelter, hot meals everyday, a good education and an opportunity to really live her life. I've visited the school myself and can say that the quality of life there is dramatically different from living in the slums. 

Although I cannot afford a visit anytime soon, I'd love to raise some funds to help with the building of a school (equipped with 2 dormitories) for HIV Positive families in Mlolongo, Kenya. They need approximately $21000 USD to make this happen. 

I've committed to walk 41K in one recorded day to show my support for this cause. This walk will occur Sunday, August 9. Myself and some other teams have committed to doing a local race that includes mental and physical challenges in Sydney, Australia that will occur Sunday, August 23rd. Since we've committed, we felt this was a great opportunity to raise money for a cause that is close to our hearts: HIV Positive women and families who need support for self-sustainability. It is an absolutely amazing organization so please give generously as you can afford of course. I'll be sure to share updates regularly!

Website: http://www.livingpositive-mlolongo.org/

                 https://livingpositivemlolongo.wordpress.com/

Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/pages/Living-Positive-Mlolongo/140634422690586?fref=ts

What We Need

  • We need $21000 to fund the completion of the school
  • Even if we don't reach our goal, the funds will all go to support this endeavour. 
  • Money goes a long way in Kenya. The money can be used for remaining building materials, water system, school supplies, mattresses, beds and so much more. 

The Impact

Allow children from HIV positive families a safe place to receive an education, have shelter and receive consistent meals. The rescue center will allow a safe place for Kenyans struggling with HIV and AIDs to receive support from the community. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't donate, please spread the word to others. This is a wonderful organization doing the best that it can with the resources it has. Even sharing this campaign with others would be amazing. If you happen to be in Kenya, reach out to the organization. They are always looking for volunteers to assist!

story:
About Us

Fusion Theatre Company are conservatoire-trained, professional, theatre practitioners, based in London. We have made it our mission to create professionally constructed shows that enhance educational standards via drama-based learning and our creative team has a cumulative 65 years in theatre and education.

Our Aim

Our mission is to fuse links between people and cultures, languages, heritage and society, using theatre as a vehicle to educate, entertain and enhance our understanding of the world.
How can we teach young people about what it means to be British?
How should they learn about what it is that unites us a country?
We all know there have been huge cuts in both arts and education, yet still it is vital to have opportunities to experience the arts within education, especially at primary school level.

With our project we aim to deliver professional shows, workshops and education packs to primary school pupils in Key Stage 1 and 2 to promote British Values, now an ofsted requirement, using drama as a tool to develop key skills. 

How do we do this?

Through the magic of theatre! We are going to create our groundbreaking devised performance of ‘Stories from Around the World’ with accompanying educational workshops.

‘Stories from Around the World’ is our visually stunning, interactive, professionally constructed, immersive, storytelling extravaganza! Captain Cook will lead the pupils on a voyage around the continents on his magical ship, HMS Endeavour! Throughout the exploration, fairytales, myths and legends from all over the world will be discovered, investigating each country’s customs, performance styles, music and languages, with some exciting and hilarious characters on the way!

To make it as informative as possible, we cover elements of the new National Curriculum 2015 in Geography, English, History, Citizenship, and SMSC. Most importantly, we celebrate different faiths and beliefs in order to promote British Values.

The children will have the opportunity to engage with the show, advance the plot and help the main characters decide whether their decisions are right or wrong. Along with this, they will be introduced to different cultures and customs from different countries around the world, how they speak, what instruments they have and what performance they do.

The children will watch and engage with the show, explore the subjects within the workshops and be encouraged to develop self-knowledge, self-esteem and self-confidence. 

What makes us unique?

Our Gender Wayang! A Balinese instrument custom made for us by a wonderful artist in Bali, specifically designed to accompany shadow puppetry, shhhh don't tell anyone yet!

What else?

  • We offer an experience you will never forget by transforming any venue into a theatrical landscape worthy of the west end. This means that each performance has a different set up; therefore no two are the same. Our aim is to transform any space into a unique and magical environment.
  • All our practitioners are current industry professionals.
  • We are one of the few companies who are assisting with the promotion of British Values using theatre as a medium to communicate.
  • Our show incorporates costumes, puppets, masks, props and instruments from all over the world, so that children can see examples drawn from each of the cultures we will explore.
  • We incorporate varied traditional performance techniques from each story's country of origin. For example, Rangda vs. the Barong, our story from Bali, is a Topeng Masked Dance.
  • The interactive performance style allows the children to advance the plot.

A Sneak Peak

Our designer Max has been planning, drawing and colouring none stop to give us an idea of some of the characters, costumes, puppets, masks and set we will be creating. 
All of the designs pull inspiration from the cultures the stories originate from along with our own sprinkle of Fusion style.

What We Need 

Contributing to our campaign would allow us to deliver our professional show, development workshops and education packs, to as many primary schools across North London as possible for £6 per student! 

This includes Islington, Haringey, Hackney, Barnet, Enfield and Camden. 

Our campaign total is £35,000! 

We would like to deliver the show to as many children as possible, across as many schools as possible.
There are 403 primary schools in North London alone!
Depending on the amount of funding we receive, we would split it up in the following ways:
£1,000 - £100 discount to 10 schools reaching 900 pupils.
£5,000 - £100 discount to 50 schools reaching 4500 pupils.
£10,000 - £100 discount to 100 schools reaching 9000 pupils.
£20,000 - £100 discount to 200 schools reaching 18000 pupils.
£30,000 - £100 discount to 300 schools reaching 27000 pupils.
The rest of the money is broken up between:
  • Props.
  • Costumes. 
  • Masks.
  • Puppets.
  • Instruments from around the world - Shamisen, Sitar, Balalaika and Bouzouki.
  • Fully functional professional set.
  • Professional sound and lighting board.
  • Wages for creative team - Actors, Director, Designers.
  • Advertising.
  • Printing and Postage.
  • CRM System.
  • Office Costs.
We realise this is nowhere near the amount of primary schools across North London. The total number of primary schools is 403! But depending on the success of our campaign we would like to expand our reach to as many of these as possible.

Perks

When you contribute to Fusion Theatre Company you will become part of the theatre in education revolution! And as a reward you can also select some perks that will help you tell others about what we are doing so they can join us too. 

Our feature perk at the £1000 receives a special performance of our show for a number of audience members at a venue to suit the donor's needs. This can be ANYWHERE! A town hall, a garden, wherever you would like to see it!

The Impact

We believe it is important to have access to theatre at all stages of life, as we feel the arts are such a crucial part of education allowing us to unlock profound human understanding, therefore we offer our shows not only in professional theatres but also within a school setting. 

Learning Outcomes:

  • Enable students to develop their self- knowledge, self- esteem and self- confidence.
  • Encourage respect for other peoples.
  • Further tolerance and harmony between different cultural traditions by enabling students to acquire an appreciation and respect for their own and other cultures.
  • Promotes the spiritual, moral, cultural, mental and physical development of pupils at the school and of society.
  • Encourage respect for democracy and support for participation in democratic processes.
  • Enable students to distinguish right from wrong and to respect the civil and criminal law.

We believe we need to educate children to appreciate the vast cultural contribution that our nation has made to the arts and indeed the world and to broaden young people’s horizons through the cultural heritage of other nations.

Our aim is to create the opportunity for everybody who attends our shows to participate in the performance, and workshops using a visual, auditory, and kinesthetic approach to learning and encouraging them to discover how theatre and the arts can enrich their lives.

If you agree with us, please make it possible for children who cannot access these tools easily by contributing to our campaign. 

The Team

Artistic Director - Katie Merritt

Artistic Director Katie Merritt is a professional theatre director who completed 5 years of study in theatre finishing with a two year Master of Fine Arts degree in theatre directing at conservatoire accredited East 15 Acting School, London. More recently she has been working as the Associate Director of Maverick Theatre Company in Soho, creating work for the British Museum and on a season of literary classics for unusual places. The beginning of her career started as a teaching assistant in a drama department, where she was able to explore theatre in education in depth, which has stimulated a passion to develop what can be offered using theatre as a tool for learning. 

As a theatre maker, her study at East 15 Acting School provided her with training in Jacques Lecoq puppet, clown and physical training and core modules examining Shakespeare, musical theatre, opera, devising, comedy and contemporary British writing. What particularly inspired her was a term studying at Institut Seni Indonesia (ISI Denpasar) on forms such as Topeng Masked Dance, Legong Dance, Wayang Kulit and an introduction to Balinese Hinduism and performance cultures and an integration of other cultures has heavily influenced her style.

 Artistic Director - Max Wolf

Max Wolf, Co-Artistic Director, trained at Middlesex University and is a professional designer who has worked with pioneering theatre companies across the UK, including The National Theatre, Old Vic Tunnels and Les Enfant Terribles as well as Danny Boyle at the Olympics Opening Ceremony.

Working as a designer has refined his abilities to create projects from inception to delivery with confidence. Designing has given him the opportunities and skills to hone his style and enhance a polished performance. His strengths are in set design and set building sound, lighting, AV, puppet and prop making. Working as technician and stage manager for established comedy clubs, large-scale theatres and festivals. 

A huge part of Max's work has been within education having been invited to lead workshops at Pegasus Theatre in Oxford, and also working at Hackney Shed for several years highlighted the importance and passion for youth theatre groups. 

Associate Writer - David Jackson

Dave Jackson trained at Middlesex University and the National Youth Theatre. He is currently artist director at the Hungry Wolf Theatre Company and an associate artist at the National Youth Theatre. As well as a guest lecturer at Chichester University. Dave is currently working on Stories from Around the World with Artistic Director Katie Merritt and is developing the show for a London debut performance. Dave co-wrote last year for ITV2 and in the past has written for BBC Radio Four. He was recently commissioned to write a play for Rodean school and is a co-founder of and a regular director at the Petersfield Shakespeare Festival. Dave has directed and written everything from children's theatre to stand up comedy to full scale plays at The Fringe and first performed there with the NYT in 1997. Working with emerging artists is something that Dave has done throughout his career as a teacher and a director. Dave is also the Director of Drama at Reigate Grammar School, and is a huge part of the creative team in terms of devising, writing and creating education packs and workshops. 

Associate Writer - Sue Blundell

Sue Blundell is a playwright and lecturer in Classical Studies. Many of her plays have been inspired by ancient myths, ideas, and objects. She has written about a wide range of aspects of the ancient world, from women in classical Greece to the symbolism of Greek and Roman shoes. Her plays have been performed at The British Museum, and at schools and colleges in Britain and the US. Her latest work, 189 Pieces, was performed at The British Museum on October 11th, and was sold out. It was produced by Maverick Theatre, and directed by Katie Merritt.
Educational Consultant - Valerie Farrow

Valerie Farrow is our educational mentor. She has worked as a headmistress for 35 years in schools in the North of England and then became an advisor to schools who required assistance raising their standards.  

Challenges

1. One of our greatest challenges is organising the logistics of a pool of actors to deliver the work in to schools.
Our main concerns:
  • Rehearsing multiple actors.
  • Giving permanent work.
  • Not offering flexibility in the first few months.
  • Expense of rehearsing more than one set of actors.
Solution
  • Offer 4 actors a working contract of 4 months. 
  • The Actors are on call with a weeks notice.
  • There has to be an amount of flexibility on both sides.
  • When the period is close to expiry, 4 more actors will be trained to add to the pool giving flexibility to both sides.
  • Repeat as growth demands.
2. As part of Stories from Around the World we will be working in depth with instruments, costumes and traditions from other countries and we are dedicated to representing them with the utmost respect and skill, as they would be performed in the native country.
This will involved making opportunities for our pool of actors with experts to provide the relevant knowledge and experience. 
This will be a two-pronged approach with the creative team at Fusion and multiple international contacts to deliver work that is true to form.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Spread the word via email, social media and word of mouth! You can follow/retweet us on Twitter and like/share our posts on Facebook! Click on the Indiegogo tools to help us out!
  • Would you like our show/workshop in your school or theatre? EMAIL US! bookings@fusiontheatre4schools.com 
  • Take a look at our website www.fusiontheatre4schools.com and pass it on! 
  • Give us your feedback! We are super passionate about our idea, but what do you think? Do you have any thoughts on how to make it better? PLEASE TELL US!

Thank you for reading.

Fusion Theatre Company.

story:
Short Summary

The volleyball program at Our Lady of the Lake University (OLLU) was started in 2007. Since that time, the team has grown from a small start up to a legitimate contender for the Red River Athletic Conference championship. This year, OLLU hosts the conference tournament for the first time and the Saints are hoping it ends with their first ever conference championship.

What We Need and What You Get

Since the program was started, very little equipment and training aids have been bought for the team. The women have been practicing in a manner where they only receive 60 percent of the reps and touches. To be able to use 100 percent of the time allotted, OLLU is requesting:

- 4 boxes to use for hitting and serving drills. These boxes allow extra swings without wearing down the players and it allows defenders a more game-like situation when working on digging the ball.

- 2 setter targets so setters can set consistently instead of being targets for each other.

- 2 passing targets so that passers can have something to aim for and the players can spend less time shagging and more time passing

Also, OLLU’s budget only covers the fall season. During the spring, OLLU would like to play in a couple of tournaments against NCAA Division 1 and 2 schools where the Saints can compete against the best teams in Texas. To do this, OLLU will need to cover:

- Rental vans for one out of town tournament

- Food and lodging for one out of town tournament and one tournament in San Antonio (food only)

Finally, OLLU wants to provide its student-athletes with the best experience possible at this amazing institution. To do this, OLLU provides the women with apparel, workout equipment and other various items which they wear to represent OLLU. In this regard, OLLU is asking for:

- Contributions to cover athletes’ meals when they report to campus before school opens

- Help defray the cost of uniforms and shoes.

The Impact

The women on this team work extremely hard to represent themselves and OLLU. Helping them with new volleyball training tools allows them to not only succeed on the court but also in the classroom. Less time wasted in practice shagging and standing means better and shorter practices which allows more time for studying. OLLU’s goal this year is to be an AVCA Academic All-American team and OLLU fans can help them with this goal!

The Saints Volleyball Team wants to represent Our lady of the Lake University not just on a local level, but on a national level. With your donations, OLLU has a better chance of doing this at the national championships in Sioux City, Iowa!

Other Ways You Can Help

In addition to giving, or if you do not have any extra cash, please support the Saints by coming to their games! OLLU will have giveaways at every home game, selected autograph sessions and even free clinics for kids (to be announced on the OLLU website). Also, all of the Saints home matches will be streamed online. 

Watch the Saints play and see what makes them a great team. Fans will see a talented team, not a collection of individuals; fans will not be disappointed.
story_txt:
Short Summary The volleyball
program at Our Lady of the Lake University (OLLU) was started in 2007. Since
that time, the team has grown from a small start up to a legitimate contender
for the Red River Athletic Conference championship. This year, OLLU hosts the
conference tournament for the first time and the Saints are hoping it ends with
their first ever conference championship.   What We Need and What You Get 
Since the
program was started, very little equipment and training aids have been bought for
the team. The women have been practicing in a manner where they only receive 60
percent of the reps and touches. To be
able to use 100 percent of the time allotted, OLLU is requesting:
- 4 boxes to
use for hitting and serving drills. These boxes allow extra swings without
wearing down the players and it allows defenders a more game-like situation
when working on digging the ball.
- 2 setter
targets so setters can set consistently instead of being targets for each
other.
- 2 passing
targets so that passers can have something to aim for and the players can spend
less time shagging and more time passing
Also, OLLU’s
budget only covers the fall season. During the spring, OLLU would like to play
in a couple of tournaments against NCAA Division 1 and 2 schools
where the Saints can compete against the best teams in Texas. To do this, OLLU
will need to cover:
- Rental
vans for one out of town tournament
- Food and
lodging for one out of town tournament and one tournament in San Antonio (food
only)
Finally, OLLU
wants to provide its student-athletes with the best experience possible at this
amazing institution. To do this, OLLU provides the women with apparel, workout
equipment and other various items which they wear to represent OLLU. In this
regard, OLLU is asking for:
-
Contributions to cover athletes’ meals when they report to campus before school
opens
- Help
defray the cost of uniforms and shoes.

    The Impact 
The women on
this team work extremely hard to represent themselves and OLLU. Helping them
with new volleyball training tools allows them to not only succeed on the court
but also in the classroom. Less time wasted in practice shagging and standing
means better and shorter practices which allows more time for studying. OLLU’s
goal this year is to be an AVCA Academic All-American team and OLLU fans can help
them with this goal!
The Saints
Volleyball Team wants to represent Our lady of the Lake University not just on
a local level, but on a national level. With your donations, OLLU has a better
chance of doing this at the national championships in Sioux City, Iowa!


    Other Ways You Can Help 
In addition
to giving, or if you do not have any extra cash, please support the Saints by
coming to their games! OLLU will have giveaways at every home game, selected
autograph sessions and even free clinics for kids (to be announced on the OLLU
website). Also, all of the Saints home matches will be streamed online. 
Watch the
Saints play and see what makes them a great team. Fans will see a talented
team, not a collection of individuals; fans will not be disappointed.

story:
I need to finish my 6th year of school, the last one! to be able to bring more consciousness into the world. 

I graduated from Healing School and decided to do two more years. One more year and I can get my title as a BIP! This title will allow me to do workshops and to help people not only through hands on healing but through one-on-one sessions talking and being very present with what is. In this sessions we find out belief systems that are stopping the client from creating the life he wants, we work with difficult emotions and people feel like they learned something new about themselves. This work is life changing and that's why I want to finish my year and receive my title.

I currently do healing and nutrition consultations. I paid for my 5 years at school and now I need your help to bring forth my longing of helping people and bringing light into this world!

The way I will use this money will be to cover my school tuition, I will also need to travel and book a hotel to be able to attend school and I will donate 10% of the contributions as a sign of gratitute.

story:
When you support this fund you help me teach people how to get beyond a literal reading of the Bible. 

I am partnering with a PR firm to get my book, "Permission Granted: Take the Bible Into Your Own Hands," more exposure. Many of the topics I discuss are relevant to current social and political conversations, including marriage equality, women's rights, and the role of faith in the public sphere. As one of my colleagues and endorsers said, my voice in this book is "a unique and important one: warm and witty, sage and occasionally snarky, but ultimately deeply reflective and profoundly serious about the troubles many people have with the Bible and how it is used by people today." (Joseph Marchal, Ball State University)

The book comes from teaching dozens of College level intro sections to both testaments of the Bible. I lost track of the number of times I heard students in those classes say, "I wish I had heard this sooner." In trying to make important content accessible to people outside of classrooms, a book emerged that is relevant to anyone - faithful Christian, Buddhist, atheist, whatever - who is interested in what is in the Bible.

story:
After ten years of success, BeadforLife is launching a global expansion of the Street Business School to ignite one million women world-wide by 2027!

BeadforLife has been igniting potential in Ugandan women for over ten years. Our unique business training model has empowered women – usually the poorest of the poor – with the skills and confidence they need to create successful and sustainable businesses. We are now on the cusp of an amazing opportunity - global expansion! 

The Ignite One Million Campaign will help us scale the Street Business School - a mobile classroom that helps women living on a dollar a day to become self-sustaining business women.  Our six-month program helps women who are living in poverty - often unable to feed their children even one meal a day.

Instead of giving them handouts, we give them the skills and confidence they need to open small businesses like vegetable stands or small restaurants. This program is helping the poorest women - those surviving on less than 65 cents a day - to quintuple their earnings.

Now, we are taking this program global, and need your support! 

Your donation today will help us reach our goal of one million dollars, which will help us ignite one million women around the world out of poverty.


After 10 years of success, BeadforLife is launching a global expansion of the Street Business School to reach one million women worldwide by 2027. 


The Street Business School

The Street Business School (SBS) training model is engaging, interactive and designed to challenge and support female entrepreneurs, as they become their own agents of change. The SBS model rests on the three core components:

1) Selecting women with entrepreneurial potential

2) Providing them with relevant and practical hands-on business training, and

3) Creating a personalized mentoring relationship to ensure success

This is not your typical business school; rather it is a mobile classroom with trainings held in the local community. 

Throughout the six-month program, training focuses on a holistic approach to preparing women as business leaders. This training includes breaking down traditional stereotypes, building confidence, providing basic education, offering simplified and practical training on market research, business plan development, procuring capital and bookkeeping. BeadforLife offers informal internships and one-on-one coaching, at which point participants discuss individual business plans and goals. If a participant has excelled, they are given working capital ranging from $20 - $120 at the end of the program to take their business to the next level.

To learn more about the expansion and Ignite One Million campaign, please check out our campaign brochure here.


Meet Our SBS Grads:


Perks

Thank you! Or say they say in Uganda, Webale-Nyo!

$12

You will be emailed a code that you can enter at checkout to get 10% off your BeadforLife online purchase now through the end of December! Act before this perk goes away!

$25

You have ignited potential in a woman and we want to remind you of your potential! In addition to the 10% off coupon code, at this level we would like to recognize your generosity with a PDF copy of our Ignite Potential poster.

$46

For $46 you are paying for a month of one woman's tuition at the Street Business School. In addition to the perks at the lower levels, we would like to honor your gift with a "grab-basket" piece of jewelry, randomly selected from our current or past collections*.

$138

For $138 you are sponsoring a woman for three months of the SBS training – that’s half of the program! For that generosity, in addition to the previously listed perks, we would like to share with you a limited-edition keychain*, made from our beautiful paper beads, as well as a coin purse* – both hand-crafted in Uganda! Plus, we want to thank you publicly and recognize you in our monthly newsletter.


$275

Karimu means to give generously, and that is what you are doing! For $275 you are paying for one woman to complete the entire SBS program! In addition to the perks listed at all previous levels, we want to give you a jewelry bag with our beautiful Karimu necklace*! And beyond recognizing you in our e-Newsletter, we want to thank you publicly on our website as well!

$1,000

You’re a power supporter! It must be hard being so generous! Why don’t you relax with a spa package? We would love to contribute our skin care line to your relaxing routine!

$8,250

You are a class act! This level gives an entire class of 30 women the opportunity to complete the Street Business School. At this level, you will be honored with hand written letters from women completing the Street Business School. Plus the opportunity to participate in a quarterly call with our Executive Director and co-Founder, Devin Hibbard, where she will give you updates an information about how the expansion project is going.

*colors and styles may vary

No Perk Necessary? Click "Contribute Now"  -  only thing we’ll send you is a heartfelt “thanks!”

About BeadforLife 

Ten years ago, three sassy women founded BeadforLife after a chance encounter opened their hearts and sparked their imagination. Torkin Wakefield, Ginny Jordan, and Devin Hibbard met Millie Grace Akena while walking through a crowded Ugandan slum.  Millie was sitting on the ground outside of her mud home, rolling small strips of paper into colorful beads in the sweltering sun. She caught their eye, and they stopped to learn more about this intriguing woman.

They soon learned that Millie was originally from Northern Uganda and had been driven from her home by Joseph Kony and the Lord’s Resistance Army. She fled to Kampala to protect her children from being kidnapped to become soldiers. To support her family, she and her five children worked in a rock quarry crushing stones into pebbles with a hand mallet. The family earned less than a dollar a day for their efforts. Our founders were taken aback by her story.  How could such hardship and struggle exist in a world where some enjoy so much material wealth?

Founder, Torkin Wakefield and Millie Grace Akena

While Millie’s story was heartbreaking, she held onto hope, determined to create a better future for her children. She found joy in transforming recycled paper into striking paper bead necklaces. The problem?  No one had the money to buy it.

Torkin, Ginny, and Devin bought a few necklaces and immediately attracted the attention of other would-be bead-wearers in Uganda. The months that followed changed the lives of everyone involved. Beads were brought back to The United States and women began opening their hearts and their homes to Ugandan women half a world away.

A Beads to Business graduate wearing and carrying her beads

Beads were only the beginning. We could have stayed the course, working with one group of women to create a product that we could sell for them in the U.S. market – but we had bigger dreams. We created an 18 month entrepreneurial business training, giving Ugandan women living in extreme poverty the skills and confidence they need to go out and create their own local businesses before they graduate.  Salons, shoe stores, and produce stands are cropping up in Uganda and women are making money and living out their dreams.  Not only do they have the income, but now they have the confidence to be sustainable businesswomen - meeting their own needs and creating a generation of confident and capable children.

We didn’t stop there. We’ve taken the best parts of that original business program and created The Street Business School. These savvy women don’t make products (for us), they make progress! They are women who have dreamed of running successful businesses, and that’s exactly what they do when they graduate, only 6 months later!

SBS graduate at her shoe store

Now, we’re taking this best poverty eradication program to the world! We know our model works, and we’re ready to share it with other movers and shakers of the world so that we can Ignite the lives of one Million women around the world! We’re dreaming big and would love for you to be a part of it. 

Goals

Join us on Indiegogo to reach one million dollars by the end of September! 

If we reach one million dollars by the end of September, select major donors have agreed to unlock their donations for a total of $300,000, getting us to our overall goal of $1.3 million dollars!  

To learn more about our Ignite One Million expansion and campaign, please click here.

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways to support BeadforLife as we ignite one million women out of poverty!

You can SHOP.

You can HOST.

You can TEACH. 

Click these links, or visit www.beadforlife.org/take-action for more information!

story:
Why Music?

"Where words fail, music speaks." -- Hans Christian Andersen

Our children need music! Research shows that music stimulates brain development, improves language skills, and inspires creative thinking. Music promotes self-discipline, social understanding, and builds bridges between communities. The lack of access to music education in today’s schools further deprives the underserved children who can benefit from it the most!  

Our most touching, celebratory, and learning experiences are often tied to music. Please help us give the gift of music to our children! 


Why MUST?

Music In Schools Today (MUST) is a non-profit based in San Francisco. Since 1983, MUST supports and develops music education programs that increase student achievement.

Ashley, newly appointed chairman of MUST's Board of Directors, launched the “Music4Kids Campaign” with a fundraising goal of $250,000.

“Music in Schools Today provides a safety net for our schools, and it needs deeper and broader community support. My goal as chair is to provide the resources to bring this excellent programming to as many children as possible.” - Dan Ashley, News Anchor at ABC-7

MUST needs to meet a $100K challenge:


We're turning to Indiegogo to raise the rest of the funds needed to secure this matching grant. An anonymous donor is offering to double every dollar you give! 

With your support, we can expand our Music Enrichment, Music Integration, Music First! and Adopt an Instrument programs. We are closing the gap so that some day every child receives a meaningful music education.



The MUST Impact

With the money we raise, we will:

  • Fund in-school artists and music programs for partner schools.

  • Raise $1,000,000+ in instruments for schools and serve more students.

About our students:

  • 90% receive financial assistance in school.

  • 80% are at-risk youth with a history of sexual abuse, suicide, and violence.

  • Students in MUST programs have seen a 50% improvement in attendance and GPA.

Other Ways To Help

Besides donating, there are several other ways you can help.

By sharing our organization's mission and campaign to your friends, family and co-workers, you are bringing us that much closer to achieving our goal! Please share, post, and tweet about our campaign. 

If you are interested in volunteer opportunities with Music In Schools Today, contact mustypn@mustcreate.org.

For more information regarding this campaign or the MUST organization, contact info@mustcreate.org.

story: .

Building a new media landscape in DR

Created and managed by young journalists, activists and academics, El Grillo is a digital newsportal openly commited to social and political transformation in the Dominican Republic. 

We focus on the struggles of traditionally excluded sectors who have little space in the mainstream media: poor communities, peasants, migrants, workers, women, social movements, LGTB community, NGOs and alternative political organizations. 

We aim to offer information which is useful to citizens striving for change and our basis is the Right to Information, a basic right that cannot be guarantee by for-profit and corporate-own traditional media. 

Apoya la información para el cambio en RD  

Elgrillo.do es el primer espacio digital dominicano directamente comprometido con el cambio social y gestionado por periodistas jóvenes, académicos y activistas. 

Nos enfocamos en visibilizar las luchas y demandas de los sectores tradicionalmente excluidos: comunidades pobres, campesinxs, migrantes, trabajadorxs, mujeres, movimientos sociales, comunidad LGTB, ONGs y grupos políticos alternativos. 

Buscamos ofrecer información útil para el cambio social y político, motivadxs en el Derecho a la Información, un derecho fundamental en las sociedad modernas y que no está garantizado por la prensa tradicional, que responde a una lógica de lucro. 

Our basic budget for 2016

With your donation you are helping guarantee the basic resources we need to operate during the next year:  

  • Hire a minimun part-time team to coordinate and create the content of the portal. This team includes an editor, a jounalist and a community manager to keep us active in the social media.
  • Cover the operational costs of the online plataform and the everyday expenses required by our journalists (transport, communications, materials). 

Lo mínimo que requerimos para 2016

Además del trabajo voluntario de lxs periodistas y ciudadanxs que participamos en este proyecto, El Grillo requiere de tu contribución para: 

  • Contar con un equipo mínimo que gestione, coordine y produzca los contenidos: un/a editor, un/a periodista y un/a community manager que mantenga activa nuestras redes sociales.
  • Cubrir gastos operativos de la plataforma digital y de la logística de trabajo de nuestras/os periodistas (transporte, comunicación, material gastable). 

Still small... but with big hopes for a great future

The Grillo began publishing on the 23th March 2015. Since then it has received up to more than 6,000 daily visits from around the world.

In these seven months El Grillo has provided information o issues such as social inequality in Dominican Republic, the dangers of mega mining, the situation of informal workers, violence against women and a critica analysis of the media coverage of feminicides. El Grillo has also echoed the manifestations of social, cultural and labor movements in the country, as well as the demands and proposals of discriminated groups, such as the LGBT community.

Our "Patria Grande" section provides information about Latin America and the rest of the world, thanks to partnerships with Telesur, Alainet, Aler.org and other agencies.

Some of the most important political debates on the electoral participation of the Dominican progressive groups in the next general elections in May 2016 have taken place in our "Ideas" section.

For these and many other reasons, we believe that, with your help, El Grillo project will make important contributions to the construction of a community, a country and a better world. We are information for change!

Lo que hemos logrado en 7 meses de vida

El Grillo comenzó sus publicaciones el 23 de marzo del 2015. Desde entonces ha recibido hasta más de 6,000 visitas diarias desde diferentes partes del mundo. 

En estos siete meses El Grillo ha servido de plataforma para visibilizar temas como la desigualdad social en República Dominicana, los peligros de la megaminería, la situación de lxs trabajadores informales, la violencia contra la mujer y la cobertura sencionalista de los medios a los casos de feminicidios. El Grillo también se ha hecho eco de las manifestaciones del movimiento social, cultural  y laboral del país, así como de las demandas y propuestas de grupos discriminados, como la comunidad LGBT.

Tomando en su sentido amplio un concepto acuñado por el libertador Simón Bolívar, nuestra sección “Patria Grande” ofrece informaciones sobre los pueblos hermanos de América Latina y el resto del mundo, gracias a acuerdos de colaboración con Telesur, Alainet, Aler.org y otras agencias solidarias.

Algunos de los más importantes debates políticos sobre la participación electoral de las agrupaciones progresistas dominicanas en las próximas elecciones generales de mayo del 2016 se han desarrollado en nuestra sección “Ideas”.

Por estas y otras tantas razones, creemos que, con tu ayuda, el proyecto El Grillo seguirá haciendo importantes aportes a la construcción de una comunidad, un país y un mundo mejor. ¡Somos información para el cambio!
story_txt:
Building a new media landscape in DR
Created and managed by young journalists, activists and academics, El Grillo is a digital newsportal openly commited to social and political transformation in the Dominican Republic. 
We focus on the struggles of traditionally excluded sectors who have little space in the mainstream media: poor communities, peasants, migrants, workers, women, social movements, LGTB community, NGOs and alternative political organizations. 
We aim to offer information which is useful to citizens striving for change and our basis is the Right to Information, a basic right that cannot be guarantee by for-profit and corporate-own traditional media. 
Apoya la información para el cambio en RD   Elgrillo.do es el
primer espacio digital dominicano directamente comprometido con el cambio
social y gestionado por periodistas jóvenes, académicos y activistas. 
Nos
enfocamos en visibilizar las luchas y demandas de los sectores tradicionalmente excluidos: comunidades pobres, campesinxs, migrantes, trabajadorxs, mujeres, movimientos
sociales, comunidad LGTB, ONGs y grupos políticos alternativos. 
Buscamos ofrecer información
útil para el cambio social y político, motivadxs en el Derecho a la Información, un derecho fundamental en las sociedad modernas y que no está garantizado por la prensa tradicional, que responde a una lógica de lucro. 
   Our basic budget for 2016 With your donation you are helping guarantee the basic resources we need to operate during the next year:    Hire a minimun part-time team to coordinate and create the content of the portal. This team includes an editor, a jounalist and a community manager to keep us active in the social media.

Cover the operational costs of the online plataform and the everyday expenses required by our journalists (transport, communications, materials). 
   Lo mínimo que requerimos para 2016 Además del trabajo voluntario de lxs periodistas y ciudadanxs que participamos en este proyecto, El Grillo requiere de tu contribución para: 
 Contar con un equipo mínimo que gestione, coordine y produzca los contenidos: un/a editor, un/a periodista y un/a community manager que mantenga activa nuestras redes sociales.

Cubrir gastos operativos de la plataforma digital y de la logística de trabajo de nuestras/os periodistas (transporte, comunicación, material gastable).     Still small... but with big hopes for a great future 
The Grillo began publishing on the 23th March 2015. Since then it has received up to more than 6,000 daily visits from around the world.
In these seven months El Grillo has provided information o issues such as social inequality in Dominican Republic, the dangers of mega mining, the situation of informal workers, violence against women and a critica analysis of the media coverage of feminicides. El Grillo has also echoed the manifestations of social, cultural and labor movements in the country, as well as the demands and proposals of discriminated groups, such as the LGBT community.

story:
Support the work of an experienced freelance journalist covering the life of refugees worldwide without censure. 

Dear people,

My name is Ali Ali, I am a photojournalist from Gaza with work experience of
more than 12 years especially in the Middle East. My pictures have been
published in prestigious newspapers such as the New York Times, Time, The
Guardian, The Los Angeles Times, Newsweek, The Independent, El País,
Süddeutsche Zeitung, Frankfurter Rundschau, De Volkskrant, Libération and I
won several awards for my work.

Further information on my work can be found here:

http://www.worldpressphoto.org/people/ali-ali

http://www.epa.eu/about-epa/awards/frontline-club-awards-2013-photojournalism


http://www.frontlineclub.com/frontline-club-awards-ceremony-2013/

http://time.com/3803758/discovering-the-next-generation-of-photojournalists-at-world-press-photos-masterclass/

http://time.com/3801405/wire-photographer-spotlight-conflict-and-conscience-in-gaza-by-ali-ali/


Since the age of 17 I have been holding a camera in my hand and put myself
in situations of war and of pain and suffering, but also captured the happy
moments, showing a smile or laughter. I have followed the life of refugees in
Gaza and documented political decisions, in trying to save a piece of history
and to show the truth through my pictures.

All those years I worked for a German Press Agency as a stock photographer
giving all my power into this work.
Almost one year ago I was invited from the agency in Germany which offered
me new possibilities to take a step further in my career. I came from Gaza
with the hope of reaching the world and making my camera a medium of
expression and communication.

Unfortunately my agency did not support me with my career here, but wanted
me to go back to work in Gaza instead. As I would face severe difficulties in
Gaza for having left the country, my way to Germany proved to be a one way
road. But as returning to Gaza is not a possibility for me, the  agency  
cancelled the contract.

As a consequence I had to give back all my equipment to the agency (2x
cameras, 2x lenses and my laptop with all the programmes for my work).
I was extremely surprised and disappointed with this development.



My Project:

Since I arrived in Germany I worked in the only job I know to do good which is
photography. I have started a project 6 months ago, where I follow refugees
here in Germany and around Europe.

My project focuses on the life of the refugees and on the mutual influence of their new environment on them and on the influence they have on their new environment.
I am aiming to point out the mutual awareness and acceptance
between the European people and the refugees as a result of their
coexistence.

I aim to capture the truth as I believe that factual communication will erase
the fear for the unknown and build bridges between the European people and
the refugees. 

I wish to support a successful integration by using photography
as an instrument of love and revelation. To achieve this, I have to find my own
stories beside the mainstream and to work independently of any agency.

What I need to continue my project:

Equipment:

In order to be able to continue my project it is the most essential for me to buy
again the equipment.

- 2 x body 5D canon : 5,200 Euro = $5,580
https://www.calumetphoto.de/product/Canon-EOS-5D-Mark-III-Gehause/CANEOS5DMIII?gclid=CjwKEAiAk7O0BRD9_Ka2w_PhwSkSJAAmKswx2z4pBQj1nRFPHh4Qk0nybZDWSUxu5Qk0v01MLHe72hoCCNPw_wcB

- 70-200 canon lens 2.8: 2,000 Euro = $2,150
http://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/product/680103-USA/Canon_2751B002_EF_70_200mm_f_2_8L_IS.html

- 16-35 canon lens: 1,200 Euro = $2,150
http://www.amazon.de/Canon-EF-16-35mm-Objektiv-Filtergewinde/dp/B000NSHPG6

Travels:

My approach is to be part of the personal life of each refugee that I am taking
pictures of  to be able to bring out what is in his/her soul. In order to do so I
have to follow each person I take a picture of for a period of time.

The countries I will shoot in:

· Germany
· France
· Belgium
· Greece
· Serbia
· Hungary

For each country I will need at least one month, depending on the
accessibility and cooperation from the different authorities.

Thus, for each country I will need approx. 1,000-1,500 Euro including:
accommodation/ travel costs to the country/ travel costs in the country/
translator (when needed)/ food

Total travel costs: 9,000 Euro = $9,674

Total equipment: 8,400 Euro = $9,029

Total Amount: 17,400 Euro = $18,700
*note: my campaign's original goal is in Euro currency but I changed it to Dollar so I can use the bank account tool to receive funds along with the Paypal tool.

To make my project happen, I sincerely need your help. 
Please support my work by contributing and\or sharing the campaign!

Thank you all!

Ali Ali

story:
Short Summary

Many children live in rural areas here in Bali, and they are not necessarily served by any form of public transport in order to go to school. While the kids in the "better" areas can take a bus, or have their parents take them to school on a motorbike, these less fortunate children often walk great distances to get to school. It can be even harder considering that their diets are often not really very substantial.

We have had requests for bikes from the Sponsor Coordinators of The Bali Childrens' Project, a registered 501C3 NGO, for children in several areas, all mostly rural where the schools are far. Bicycles would be a great help for the children to get to school. Right now it's a struggle.

The average basic cost of a boy's bike is IDR 1,600,000 and for a girls IDR 1,800,000. These are basic costs.

We are hoping to supply 25 children who need bikes. We're still waiting for a few names and photos.  They would be mostly from outlying areas where it is hard for them to attend school without some form of transportation. A bike is the perfect solution!

The program is such a fantastic idea and will be such an immediate and significant help to every one of these children. 

Thank you so much for your generosity and care, and for making school attendance possible for those children living on remote areas!

story:
School matters...

I'd been living in Kathmandu for two years when the earthquake we'd all been fearing struck on 25th April 2015.

For 8,617 people it was fatal. I was lucky to survive and am luckier still to have a roof over my head. 473,000 houses were destroyed, as well as many schools

Thousands across the country remain homeless living in make-do dwellings and many school children, eager to study, returned after the earthquake to schools which were cobbled together and could best be described as rickety, leaking shacks, exposed to the elements.


Sustainability matters...

Project SEWA aims to build new, safe, durable schools using the low-cost, sustainable Earthbag building technique that has been proven time and again around the world to withstand earthquakes.

Our project begins in the village of Jaubari, in the Gorkha district, where the greatest damage was witnessed. This project is sustainable on a number of levels: 

  • it uses local, easily extractable materials, notably earth and bamboo

  • it will employ local manpower providing jobs and contributing to the local   economy

  • it has been conceived by local expert consultants with more than a decade of experience in Earthbag construction. 

But ultimately this project is sustainable because it takes account of and responds to the expressed needs of the community. 

It's sustainable and it's achievable. Easily achievable!


Planning matters....

The plans have been drawn up for a four-classroom school. The villagers of Jaubari and the Principal, teachers and students of Shree Paropkar Adarsh Higher Secondary School have given the thumbs up to the Earthbag school construction.

They are waiting excitedly for the work to begin, and are hoping to move into their new school before the harsh, winter weather arrives.

We have already raised just over half of the estimated building costs, by other means. We are aiming to raise the remaining 4,700 USD to cover the full cost of construction. This will include the local engineers' consultancy fees, the cost of training and employing semi-skilled labour and villagers, the cost of materials and tools, transportation and unforeseen operational costs.


We matter...

We are three friends eager to see this school built: Karen, a palliative care nurse with experience of working in hospice in Nepal; Ajay, a hands-on Nepali with a passion for helping his country; and myself, Flora, with an eye for a project worth supporting. 

Many others, friends, family, colleagues, and acquaintances, all touched by the students' fervour for learning, make up the crowd that has helped so far to raise the first chunk of money. Donate here to join our crowd!


YOU matter...

Only with your help can we make this happen. You can help by donating, We gratefully accept any amount, small, medium or large.

You can help by spreading the word about this project amongst your circle of friends and family.

                                                              

                          WE THANK YOU FROM THE BOTTOM OF OUR HEARTS

story:
We need your help

Hello everyone! We want to start by thanking you for your time in advance. We are the Russian National Lacrosse Team. Our goal is to make it to the European Lacrosse Championships. 
We are not asking for a free ride, we funded ourselves before, but this time around we need your help in offsetting costs due to the economic situation in our country.
As you might already know, the plunge in oil prices and economic sanctions have crippled our currency by 50%. Due to this, all of our costs doubled, and since the Championships are held abroad and our Lacrosse gear is also imported and priced in foreign currency, we can no longer afford this by ourselves. 
We don't need you to carry us to the Championships, however if we don't get some help, we will not be able to go at all. Half of our roster is composed of students, and for them, it is especially difficult to fund their trips, even with the help of their parents at this point. 

Any little bit helps

This can't be more true now than ever. Each player has to pay about $2,000 for the whole trip. We are a 23 man roster, so we are only asking for help to cover a quarter of our expenses. Your donations will go towards:

  • Purchasing necessary equipment
  • Purchasing additional uniforms for new players
  • Easing the costs of registration fees, food and accommodation
  • In the event that we can't go, the donations will go towards purchasing equipment for our Youth and University programs


Give us a chance to compete

We are interested in Lacrosse, and only in Lacrosse. We don't get involved in politics, however we must suffer the consequences from them. We are innocent bystanders, and we are at risk of losing a chance to show the effort and progress we have been practicing to achieve. We thank you again for your time and support.

story:
Short Summary

This campaign is about to create a freely available open access book under creative commons named "Medical Physiology in Modelica" and collect resources to support us to fully focus on this work for several months. 

We are scientists, PhD students, postdocs integrating medicine, biology, mathematics, computer science and graphical design. One of our activity is to write mathematical models. We use mathematical models in educational and simulation games and we used to for research as well. But we realized that many modeling technology are not intuitive for non-technical experts and allows bad practices. Lot of the models are hard or nearly imposible to maintain. And we found that Modelica language can deal with such issue. Thus, in the past we authored free opensource Modelica libraries  Physiolibrary (1st library award at Modelica Conference 2014) and Chemical (1st library award at Modelica Conference 2015).

And now we would like to document our effort and spread the knowledge how to build simple or complex models of human physiology that are still understandable for non-technical experts.

What We Need & What You Get

  • Our goal is to get 25 thousands of euros. This will be used to support the work on writing the book, refining the existing examples of physiological models in Modelica (from www.physiolibrary.org), proofreading, refining and documenting the examples of models and start of promoting them on organized tutorials and workshops.
  • You will get web edition of the book free under creative commons license, so not only contributors, but all people will get access to this book not be limited by the price and availability of it. Significant contributor will receive additional bonus (offline PDF, ebook format, physical printed copy, acknowledgment in the book, sponzorship note in the title page).
  • The first release of the book will be next IEEE Engineering in Biology and Medicine Society conference in 2016. Final release will be next Modelica conference, in 2017.
  • If we will not reach the goal of 25 thousands of EUR, we will try support creation of at least proportional part of the book.

The Impact

The book is intended

  • to educate biomedical engineers, to improve knowledge transfer from technology to healthcare
  • to educate medical doctors not to understand only data patterns, but also relations and dynamics  of normal and pathological states

We found that the open standard "Modelica" seems to highly facilitate the learning progress and allows to focus on principles of different domains. Therefore in the past we release free open source Modelica library for modeling physiology http://www.physiolibrary.org
We already have some exemplar Modelica models and documented some of the technological aspects in scientific journals or popularized in scientific and industry conferences and events. This book will consolidate and complement the results in a readable and coherent unit.

Why Indiegogo

Next to scientific funding and grants, we would try get support from different resource, community experts, which will give us flexibility from classical scientific grant deadlines, strict condition, limited purpose.

Risks & Challenges

There is risk that we will not achieve the goal. We feel that this book will still be beneficial for our activities therefore proportional part of the book will be created.

There is a probability that we will be involved in another major scientific project, which will prevent us to focus on writing this book. In such case only the part of the team will be dedicated to do the writing and the releases of the book will be postponed.

Other Ways You Can Help

Are you/Have you developed some models e.g. in Modelica? We will welcome reviewers of our chapters and examples.

donate us via BITCOIN address 3N1wo1s7HkXJKQD2jYZtMnxYxxkjk8X4kZ
story_txt:
Short Summary


 
This campaign is about to create a freely available open access book 
under creative commons named "Medical Physiology in Modelica" and 
collect resources to support us to fully focus on this work for several 
months. 
We are scientists, PhD 
students, postdocs integrating medicine, biology, mathematics, 
computer science and graphical design. One of our activity is to write mathematical models. We use mathematical models in educational and simulation games and we used to for research as well. But we realized that many modeling technology are not intuitive for non-technical experts and allows bad practices. Lot of the models are hard or nearly imposible to maintain. And we found that Modelica language can deal with such issue. Thus, in the past we authored free opensource Modelica libraries  Physiolibrary (1st library award at Modelica Conference 2014) and Chemical (1st
 library award at Modelica Conference 2015). 
And now we would like to document our effort and spread the knowledge how to build simple or complex models of human physiology that are still understandable for non-technical experts.

  What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is to get 25 thousands of euros. This will be used to support the
 work on writing the book, refining the existing examples of physiological models in Modelica (from www.physiolibrary.org), proofreading, refining and documenting the 
examples of models and start of promoting them on organized tutorials 
and workshops. 

You will get web edition of the book free under creative commons license, so not only contributors, but all people will get access to this book not be limited by the price and availability of it. Significant contributor will receive additional bonus (offline PDF, ebook format, physical printed copy, acknowledgment in the book, sponzorship note in the title page). 

The first release of the book will be next IEEE Engineering in Biology and Medicine Society conference in 2016. Final release will be next Modelica conference, in 2017.
If we will not reach the goal of 25 thousands of EUR, we will try support creation of at least proportional part of the book.


 
 The Impact 
The book is intended 

to educate biomedical engineers, to improve knowledge transfer from technology to healthcare

to educate medical doctors not to understand only data 
patterns, but also relations and dynamics  of normal and pathological states


We found that the open 
standard "Modelica" seems to highly facilitate the learning progress and allows to focus on principles of 
different domains. Therefore in the past we release free open source Modelica library for modeling physiology http://www.physiolibrary.orgWe already have some exemplar Modelica models and documented some of the 
technological aspects in scientific journals or popularized in 
scientific and industry conferences and events. This book will consolidate and complement the results in a readable and coherent unit.    Why Indiegogo
Next to scientific funding and grants, we would try get support from different resource, community experts, which will give us flexibility from classical scientific grant deadlines, strict condition, limited purpose.
Risks & Challenges There is risk that we will not achieve the goal. We feel that this book will still be beneficial for our activities therefore proportional part of the book will be created. 
There is a probability that we will be involved in another major scientific project, which will prevent us to focus on writing this book. In such case only the part of the team will be dedicated to do the writing and the releases of the book will be postponed.

story:
Rescuing Christian Families in the Middle East

Last month Glenn Beck announced his intention to rescue 400 besieged families from destruction in the Middle East by raising $10 million to bring them here and sponsor them in the United States. The American Millennium Online blog would like to do our part. In creating this campaign I hope to raise $10,000 from local residents to donate directly to Mercuryone.org's Nazarene Fund. All of the funds will be used for that cause and for no other. In addition, if you can't donate, I would like individuals to approach they church congregations to ask for their blessing to support a Christian Family coming here from Iraq until such time as they can return home or they can establish themselves legally here in the United States. If you secure your church's support for sponsorship of a family, we would like to here about it here. 

Regards, Jeremy Griffith, Creator of The American Millennium Online

story:
Freedrama Helps New Actors, Teachers and Students

Freedrama.net provides free play scripts and help for new actors.  There are resources for teachers and students as well.  Everything is free for educational use.

  • Freedrama has been online since 2001
  • We receive over 1,000,000 visitors a month
  • We help new actors, teachers and students

Remember, keep it concise, yet personal. Ask yourself: if someone stopped reading here would they be ready to make a contribution?

We need a new computer

A website needs a good computer.  We created art, videos and scripts as well as games and lessons.   It's all very hard to do without a good computer and ours are getting old.

  • We would like to buy an Apple MacBook Pro for around $1999 (either used refurbished or new depending on what is available)

More Art, Writing and Videos!

With your help, we'll be able to create more art, writing and videos for the website!  Especially art and videos (writing isn't too tough on the old computers).

Other Ways You Can Help

Even $1 is great!  If every person that visited the Freedrama.net website in one day gave a dollar, we'd have more than enough money.  

But if you can't, please share this with others and see if they can help. 

Thank you!

Doug and Shiela Larson

story:
Youth Leadership Development Program 

My name is Dayne Pilgrim.  I have worked with youth for over 10 years, creating programs that stimulate them to discover their passion, become leaders and take action to be a meaningful contributor to their community.  Now I have created a program that gives them the opportunity to have an impact on the world.

On September 26, 2015 I will be running from Scarborough City Hall, to Toronto City Hall and ending at Mississauga City Hall to raise awareness of the importance of youth leadership.  I have created a Youth Leadership Development Program (YLDP) that includes a basketball league and a leadership development program.  The program emphasis on personal leadership development in an interpersonal setting.

The need for developing youth to be effective leaders is paramount in securing a better future for the country, starting with each person doing their part.  When youth are given skills to lead effectively their opportunities to be change makers that help economies increase.

The YLDP is a multi-layered program.  It connects youth to professionals in various fields to provide them with excellent references for employment and other future endeavours.  The program consists of participants from different communities throughout the GTA to bridge gaps and focus on common challenges faced by differences.  Jobs will be created and growth in the mental, physical and social aspects are all addressed.

By contributing to this initiative you will have helped youth who do not have adequate resources to fund, find or participate in sports leagues and leadership programs.  By supporting this initiative you will have helped youth expand their network and open the opportunity for them to be mentored by professional Athletes, Police Officers, the EMS and the Fire Department.  You will also be providing an avenue for continuous support from mentors.  That kind of support has the potential to change the entire landscape of an industry and the world.  


What I Need

To run the program I need $70,000.  The money will be used to rent space for the basketball league, hire referees, staff, administrative support and buy equipment and materials such as uniforms and basketballs.


The Impact

Why am I doing this?  I am a service oriented family minded husband and father.  My drive is to provide the best possible contribution that serves everyone in an uplifting way.  I believe strengthening people through personal development and helping them reach their potential puts them in positions to help others.  The YLDP strengthens youth physically, mentally, and socially through sport, personal development and networking. 

With over 10 years of experience working with youth throughout the Greater Toronto Area and across Canada for various programs in many positions I know there are not enough programs that are multi-layered and focus on developing youth as this program is.


Risks & Challenges

To have the impact I plan for I need the program to include participants throughout the Greater Toronto Area, including mentors.  The challenge with that is I getting the word out.  My goal is to start by including youth from Metro and York region.  I need your help in getting the word out there.    

I am tapping into social media and pounding the pavement every opportunity I get to spread the word to the community leaders, media, Police, Fire, Ambulance Athletes and more.


Join me in providing an opportunity for youth to secure a brighter future.
