story:
"Who, who are we....?" Bradford and Christine Williams, aka "Pepper Berries Urban Farm" 

     Bradford and I have been gardening for 29 years.   When we started we had no one to actually teach us with "hands on" so we read a lot of books and tried ideas by success and failure method.  We stayed at it, we learned how to preserve our produce from the garden the same way.  We would of loved to have someone show us with a "hands on method". 

  Over the years we were able to feed our 5 children from our garden all year long.  If we had not started gardening, canning and freezing our food I don't know how we would of made it trying to keep 5 mouths feed, (4 were boys).  Over the last 7 years I have had the opportunity to work with a program called "Eating from the Garden".  With this program I go into the schools, community centers, homeless shelters and after school programs and teach how to cook from their gardens that they have planted at the facility.  I love to teach people how to cook, can and preserve their food that they worked so hard for in their garden.  I love to show people how they can provide for their family from their own back yards.  How they can provide nutritious meals at the fraction of the price.  Without chemicals, preservatives, high fructose sugar, msg, etc. in their food so their kids will be stronger and not have so many physical problems.

  With this campaign you will be helping to build a certified kitchen where we will be teaching classes on canning, freezing and cooking.  We will be also teaching classes on gardening in small spaces.  We have removed the failures by learning from our mistakes and giving them the opportunity to succeed to improve their daily living. "Building one person, one family , one community at a time!"

  Our campaign is to build a certified kitchen in a 2nd house we have on our property.  We will need to put up washable walls in the kitchen area and remove one wall to make a larger kitchen  for our classes to be held.  We will be upgrading the electrical and plumbing so it will be able to handle the larger volume of appliances and sinks.  We will be putting in a walk-in cooler and buying a commercial freezer, stove, sinks and dish washer.  By helping our campaign you will be helping families of all economic situations (especially low income families) to help make their food budget decrease by learning to grow their food in small spaces, how to put their food up for future days with canning, freezing, dehydration and other methods.  This will increase the healthy foods and lower the food budget that they can serve their families.  We believe that in today's economic stress families are needing a place to learn, with a hands on method of cooking, canning, freezing, dehydrating and freeze drying the food that they have grown  to help their families make ends meet.

By helping support our campaign you will be helping to invest in lives of families in the Independence/Kansas City area.  You will be helping low income families be able to take pride in providing for their families by suppling healthy low cost food to their children and their selves. 

  Our goal on this campaign is to raise $20,000.  This will help to build a certified kitchen for the families to come in and put their abundant tomato crop up.  They will not have to invest in the canning supplies to be able to save $ by processing their spaghetti sauce that they worked so hard in growing.  They will be able to pressure cook their green beans to preserve them for the winter months.  They will be able to dehydrate their fresh basil & oregano to be able to cook with throughout the 4 seasons.  These families will be able to freeze their strawberries with a process that will keep the air out of the bags to keep their product as fresh as possible without freezer burn. They will learn to make beef stew or chicken soup and how to preserve it through canning for a fast easy meal .  They will have the opportunity to come in and do once a month cooking to help them save time and money for their families.

  We are trying to get a grant (15,000.) with the SARE program that will help build the kitchen also.  This grant will fund 50% of the cost to build a certified kitchen with all the tools that a family could use to lower their food budget.  We are partnering with several low income identities to help reach families such as Ivanhoe Community Center and Farmers Market, Raytown Farmers Market, Swope Memorial, Community Service Leagues of Jackson County, CAPA, Salvation Army, Hawthorn Community Center, Cultivate KC and University of MO as well as some local churches.  With these partners helping us reach the low income and helping teach gardening, cooking, canning, freezing and dehydration classes we will be able to see a change in the families overall health and financial situations by taking the load off of the head of the household, by helping lower the monthly food budget, physical exercise in the garden and by healthier eating. 

With supporting this campaign you will also be awarded some of the jellies and jams, relishes, apple butter etc. that we can for our customers at farmers markets, bakery and local store.  You will have the opportunity to try some of the products that they will be learning to make in the certified kitchen.  You will be able to taste the freshness, see the ingredients no preservatives, no high fructose corn syrup, no msg,  in the food they will be learning to grow, can and preserve. 

If by chance we don't reach our goal we have choose the option to use whatever we can raise to reach the goal.  In other words if we only raise 1/2 of our goal we will start work on the kitchen with what we have and keep plugging away at our goal.  (Pressing toward the mark that God has called us to). With all of us helping with a little or a lot we will eventually be able to help the low income families in the Kansas City area help support their families with pride without a hands out but a hands up!

The Impact our campaign will have on our community……

By helping us raise funds to build a certified kitchen ( to teach low income families how to garden, cook, and put their food up for future months or to sell at markets to raise their income level) you will be helping the entire community.  You will be helping them improve their lives and the lives of their children with better food choices, physical activity, and learning a skill that they will be able to use the rest of their lives.  They will be learning how to grow food using the techniques that are best siuted to their life's circumstances, whether it is in an apartment, small house with not much yard or a decent size yard.  They will be able to learn container gardening, vertical, square foot, no lawn, lasagna, hay bale gardening and more.  It doesn’t matter where they live they can garden! They will be able to take the next step of gardening, "What do I do with all this produce now!" They will learn how to can, freeze, dehydrate and freeze dry it.  Or maybe they choose to sell part of it to a local store or farmers market; they will learn what they need to do to be an entrepreneur. They will be shown what markets they can sell in and have a certified kitchen to work out of at a reasonable price.

There are Risks & Challenges to this campaign just like anything we do in life….

There are always risk and challenges to anything that we do in life and this campaign is not any different.  Some of the risks are …..  Will bugs over take my crop. Will it be too rainy or to dry?  Will we be able to get families to care enough to want to make a difference in their lives and their families lives?, will I be able to get enough funds to get a kitchen built?  Will I be able to manage my project and make it successful?  Let us address each one of these risk and concerns.

  1. Yes bugs, rain and drought will put a damper on  garden plans but that is part of our growing process.  How do we overcome the obstacle and teach that to others?  For instance this year was a very strange year for growing in the Kansas City area.  We had a beautiful early spring.  We had a lot out in our garden in March and April and we were selling produce at market by the first of May, then the rains hit.  It rained and rained and rained!  We had flooding in the garden and had to go out and work on another area to control the water flow.  It rained so much that we got very little planted in May and June.  We did pick our first tomatoes to eat by the last week in May and was able to start selling some by June 15 but we still didn’t have much in the ground.  We just extended our garden area by 6 ft. X30 ft.  We were able to get the beds made the seeds and plants in the ground and finished up that night at 9:00.  We went back out the next morning and finished the last of the plantings when it started raining again.  It pored buckets and buckets of water down from the sky and we also got all of the down pour from the neighborhood.  There were rivers of rapids and waterfalls crashing down in the empty lot next to our house and it went like a mighty river toward our garden.  When it was over there was a little bit that had washed out from the spring planting  but… the new part of the garden was totally washed out.  There was a big pile of mud and plants at the bottom of the garden.  It was discouraging knowing all the work we had just done was lost.  We didn’t give up,,, we started to dig a L shaped trench around the new area it was 12 x 40 ft long, and 9 in. deep, 3 in wide.  We did this all by hand while it was still lightly raining.  When the heavy rain hit again later that day it caught and controlled the flow around the garden and held.  Success!!  Now to plant again when it was dry enough.  I first went through the mud pile at the bottom of the garden and managed to save about 20 plants and put them back into pots to wait for the day to replant.  That day did finally come even though we did not get all the seeds back in the ground we did get the plants in and they are still producing and it is now November 9, 2015.  We still have huckleberry, eggplant, peppers and tomatillos growing strong from that flood.  We had others problem throughout the garden because of the very wet growing season but overall we succeed in a tough situation and overcame many obstacles with much hard work and endurance to see it through.

  2. Yes I believe we will be able to get families to come out and take advantage of the classes, techniques and kitchen that we will have for them to utilize by working closely with the community centers, community service league, salvation army and churches.  We will need to help access their housing situation, teach them the best way of gardening for their circumstances, teach them some gardening skills and then help them walk through the steps of saving their produce that will be the best for their situation.  If they don’t have freezer room they might need to can or dehydrate everything.  Maybe they don’t need so many green peppers and eggplants, how can they sell these to bring in a little $ to buy some meat for their family.  We will be there to help them take the next step, just like our motto stays “Building one person, one family, one community at a time”

  3. What if we don’t raise enough funds to build the kitchen?  We do what we have always done, we work with what we have….  We teach the gardening classes and teach individual classes whenever we need to in their home or in mine.  Not the perfect situations but it will work.  We build the kitchen a piece at a time until the whole puzzle fits together.

  4. Will we be able to manage our projects and make it successful?  Yes I believe we can we have been working toward this goal for 30 years.  Learning one piece of the puzzle at a time, learning the ends and outs of it.  Now is the time to put all the pieces together and see the beautiful picture that it makes.  A picture that will help low income families learn to grow, cook and preserve the food they need and want to have a healthy productive life.  One where they will be learning new skills, nutrition and exercise to improve their daily lives.  Where they will have the choice to eat healthy at a fraction of the cost and a fraction of the daily cooking time. 

      HOW CAN YOU HELP?

      Will you help us put this puzzle together to “build one person, one family, one community at a time”?  If you cannot help financially there are still other ways to help work on this puzzle together….

  1. Please tell others about our project campaign by word of mouth, Facebook, twitter, emails, etc.  The more you share the louder our campaign will be heard!!  We need everyone to be talking about how they can help the low income in the Kansas City/Independence area to move up the ladder to self-reliance in gardening, canning and bring in income from their produce.

  2. We will also be needing individuals that have the same passion that we do for the low income to help at the farm with gardening, canning, cooking, etc. classes.  Contact us and let us help you be part of the puzzle to build this campaign together.  Never know, you might be the one puzzle piece that we are missing!!!

  3. Other ways you can help..  do you have a rain barrel not being used, garden tools, forms that we can use for vertical gardens, pots, etc.  Let us know so we can use these to help the low income build what they are needing to improve their daily lives.

    Please remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!!!!

that we can for our customers at farmers markets, bakery and local
store.  You will have the opportunity to try some of the products that
they will be learning to make in the certified kitchen.  You will be able
to taste the freshness, see the ingredients no preservatives, no high fructose
corn syrup, no msg,  in the food they will be learning to grow, can and
preserve. 
If by chance we don't reach our goal
we have choose the option to use whatever we can raise to reach the goal. 
In other words if we only raise 1/2 of our goal we will start work on the
kitchen with what we have and keep plugging away at our goal.  (Pressing
toward the mark that God has called us to). With all of us helping with a
little or a lot we will eventually be able to help the low income families in
the Kansas City area help support their families with pride without a hands out
but a hands up!
The
Impact our campaign will have on our community……
By helping us raise funds to build a
certified kitchen ( to teach low income families
how to garden, cook, and put their food up for future months or to sell at markets
to raise their income level) you will be helping the entire community.  You will be helping them improve their lives
and the lives of their children with better food choices, physical activity,
and learning a skill that they will be able to use the rest of their lives.  They will be learning how to grow food using the techniques that are best siuted to their life's circumstances, whether it is in
an apartment, small house with not much yard or a decent size yard.  They will be able to learn container
gardening, vertical, square foot, no lawn,
lasagna, hay bale gardening and more.  It
doesn’t matter where they live they can garden! They will be able to take the next step of
gardening, "What do I do with all this produce now!" They will learn how to can,
freeze, dehydrate and freeze dry it.  Or
maybe they choose to sell part of it to a local store or farmers market; they
will learn what they need to do to be an entrepreneur. They will be shown what
markets they can sell in and have a certified kitchen to work out of at a reasonable
price. 
There
are Risks & Challenges to this campaign just like anything we do in life….
There are always risk and challenges
to anything that we do in life and this campaign is not any different.  Some of the risks are …..  Will bugs over take my crop. Will it be too rainy
or to dry?  Will we be able to get
families to care enough to want to make a difference in their lives and their
families lives?, will I be able to get enough funds to get a kitchen built?  Will I be able to manage my project and make
it successful?  Let us address each one
of these risk and concerns.

Yes bugs, rain and drought will put a damper
on  garden plans but that is part of our growing process.  How do we overcome the obstacle and teach that
to others?  For instance this year was a
very strange year for growing in the Kansas City area.  We had a beautiful early spring.  We had a lot out in our garden in March and
April and we were selling produce at market by the first of May, then the rains
hit.  It rained and rained and rained!  We had flooding in the garden and had
to go out and work on another area to control the water flow.  It rained so much that we got very little
planted in May and June.  We did pick our
first tomatoes to eat by the last week in May and was able to start selling
some by June 15 but we still didn’t have much in the ground.  We just extended our garden area by 6 ft. X30 ft.  We were able to get the beds made the seeds and plants in the ground and finished up that night
at 9:00.  We went back out the next morning and finished the last of the
plantings when it started raining again. 
It pored buckets and buckets of water down from the sky and we also got
all of the down pour from the neighborhood. 
There were rivers of rapids and waterfalls crashing down in the empty
lot next to our house and it went like a mighty river toward our garden.  When it was over there was a little bit that
had washed out from the spring planting  but… the new part of the garden was totally
washed out.  There was a big pile of mud
and plants at the bottom of the garden. 
It was discouraging knowing all the work we had just done was lost.  We didn’t give up,,, we started to dig a L shaped
trench around the new area it was 12 x 40 ft long, and 9 in. deep, 3 in wide.  We did this all by hand while it was still
lightly raining.  When the heavy rain hit
again later that day it caught and controlled the flow around the garden and
held.  Success!!  Now to plant again when it was dry
enough.  I first went through the mud
pile at the bottom of the garden and managed to save about 20 plants and put
them back into pots to wait for the day to replant.  That day did finally come even though we did
not get all the seeds back in the ground we did get the plants in and they are
still producing and it is now November 9, 2015. 
We still have huckleberry, eggplant, peppers and tomatillos growing
strong from that flood.  We had others
problem throughout the garden because of the very wet growing season but
overall we succeed in a tough situation and overcame many obstacles with much
hard work and endurance to see it through.
Yes I believe we will be able to get
families to come out and take advantage of the classes, techniques and kitchen
that we will have for them to utilize by working closely with the community
centers, community service league, salvation army and churches.  We will need to help access their housing
situation, teach them the best way of gardening for their circumstances, teach them
some gardening skills and then help them walk through the steps of saving their
produce that will be the best for their situation.  If they don’t have freezer room they might
need to can or dehydrate everything. 
Maybe they don’t need so many green peppers and eggplants, how can they
sell these to bring in a little $ to buy some meat for their family.  We will be there to help them take the next
step, just like our motto stays “Building one person, one family, one community
at a time”
What if we don’t raise enough funds
to build the kitchen?  We do what we have
always done, we work with what we have…. 
We teach the gardening classes and teach individual classes whenever we
need to in their home or in mine.  Not the
perfect situations but it will work.  We
build the kitchen a piece at a time until the whole puzzle fits together.

Will we be able to manage our projects
and make it successful?  Yes I believe we can we have been working toward this goal for 30 years.  Learning one piece of the puzzle at a time,
learning the ends and outs of it.  Now is
the time to put all the pieces together and see the beautiful picture that it
makes.  A picture that will help low
income families learn to grow, cook and preserve the food they need and want to
have a healthy productive life.  One where
they will be learning new skills, nutrition and exercise to improve their daily
lives.  Where they will have the choice to
eat healthy at a fraction of the cost and a fraction of the daily cooking
time.  
  HOW CAN YOU HELP?
  Will you help us put this puzzle together
to “build one person, one family, one community at a time”?  If you cannot help financially there are
still other ways to help work on this puzzle together….



Please tell others about our project campaign
by word of mouth, Facebook, twitter, emails, etc.  The more you share the louder our campaign
will be heard!!  We need everyone to be
talking about how they can help the low income in the Kansas City/Independence
area to move up the ladder to self-reliance in gardening, canning and bring in
income from their produce.
We will also be needing individuals
that have the same passion that we do for the low income to help at the farm
with gardening, canning, cooking, etc. classes. 
Contact us and let us help you be part of the puzzle to build this
campaign together.  Never know, you might
be the one puzzle piece that we are missing!!!

Other ways you can help..  do you have a rain barrel not being used,
garden tools, forms that we can use for vertical gardens, pots, etc.  Let us know so we can use these to help the
low income build what they are needing to improve their daily lives.
Please remember to use the Indiegogo share tools!!!!

story:
Updates

The 1st version is now available for download at http://bit.ly/icanhelpthekids 

  • Be a VOLUNTEER!!!!!
  • We are sincerely asking you, parents, guardians, educators and volunteers to help us further improve this app by sending suggestions, questions, guide and sample exam to itbayanihan@cawayan.com. 
  • We will be releasing more questions and topics soon in our future version. All your inputs will be added to our future release and credited to you as one of the contributors. 
  • We will also be giving out token of appreciation to those who will help. 
  • THIS is the very 1st CROWD SOURCE EDUCATIONAL CONTENT App.

Short Summary

This project was conceived to help those kids with no access to proper textbook.

  • My wife loves to make study guide for our eldest daughter  and it began to pile up already on my laptop.
  • We decided to convert this study guide to FREE APP which other parents or guardians can download.
  • You as a contributor can help us create more module. Currently there are only 10 questions per module. This APP has only 6 modules.

We hope that your generosity can help more less fortunate students and young kids to access the FREE Educational Materials.

What We Need & What You Get

  • We need to raise at least $3,500 to create more module for the kids.
  • Once you sign up as our funders we will give you a surprise gift from the children benefactors of AralTAYO Campaign.
  • The excess money will be used to buy affordable small screen tablets for public schools.

Other Ways You Can Help

We know you may not be able to help us right now financially but we believe in the goodness of your heart. You can help us reach more people by helping us to campaign this project in your social media, please click the link below;

  • Twitter: #AralTAYO. EVERY Kid NEEDS a CHAMPION and I am their Champion. http://bit.ly/iSupportAralTAYO
  • Facebook: #AralTAYO EVERY Kid NEEDS a CHAMPION and I am their Champion.  http://bit.ly/iChampionAralTAYO

You can also include the hashtag #AralTAYO in all your posts.

story:
Short Summary

We are a rural district, pre-K through 12th grade, of about 1,000 students. Our district has been serving the Chimacum, Port Hadlock, Irondale, and Port Ludlow communities since 1948 and our children need the best we can offer to propel them into their futures in a 21st Century highly technological world. Families find it difficult to find jobs in this area so they either travel long distances to the city or live in poverty. Our students do not have access to technology at home so it is up to our schools to provide for our students.

We have a plan to put the passion and control of learning into our students' hands while preparing them to compete and thrive in the 21st Century. Our district has facilities that are falling apart. It is for that reason that we are running bonds and capital levies whose focus are on upgrading and fixing our desperately needed buildings. While we understand the utmost importance of having buildings that are functional and comfortable for our students we also see the need to provide them with the tools needed to learn in those upgraded accommodations.

Our middle school with approximately 250 students in grades 6 through 8 has proposed a plan where each student would get his and her own device to show them all how to use current technologies to connect, communicate, collaborate, and create using the critical thinking and problem solving skills needed to succeed. We are requesting the funds to put those devices in our kids' hands so that we may create a model that the rest of the district can follow.

Here's a shortened link to the plan we at the middle school came up with years ago that is still valid and is just waiting on some funding:
goo.gl/nqdGPi

Once the facilities are fixed and updated to serve our children in the next two years we can run a technology levy to implement the middle school one-to-one model in the rest of our schools. The funds requested in this campaign will jump start our plan to bring our children into the 21st Century and prepare them to be successful, contributing members of our great nation and our world!

What We Need & What You Get

What we need are enough Chromebook Flips, costing around $300 each, for each student and teacher in our middle school. With those 260 devices (250 students and 10 teachers) the middle school will design a one-to-one student-to-device plan that can be replicated by our primary, elementary, and high schools. Our plan will be available for any school looking to implement a one-to-one technology program their school.

Middle school students will share all the incredible things they will be doing with their devices and share how having a Chromebook Flip will prepare them for a successful future.

Those who invest in our kids' futures will get personal videos and written thank you's showing all the ways students are taking control of their learning in school. We are expecting to see increased attendance and increased test scores as students see that learning in school can be fun, exciting and relevant to their era.

If we don't get enough money to start a full one-to-one for every student in the middle school there are two back up plans that we can implement. Plan A, is of course, to have one Chromebook Flip for every child in Chimacum Middle School. Plan B is to have one Chromebook Flip for every child in Chimacum Middle School's 6th grade, approximately 67 devices. And Plan C is to start an after school club for those students who are ready to use a Chromebook Flip in their classes, approximately 20 devices. Those students will serve as the tech support and experts when we do get enough money to equip every child! Having students who take the lead to show teachers and their fellow students how to use devices in school to do great things is an effective way to integrate new technologies in schools.

    The Impact

    We all have the responsibility to prepare our children for jobs that haven't been created yet and to solve problems that don't even exist yet! As a teacher I know that I can do that better if my students have access to technology tools. I have been getting grants to equip all my students with technology to learn how best to implement a one-to-one plan for every student in every classroom no matter what course. The technology in my classroom is getting old and I am ready to spread what I've learned to the other teachers in my school, Chimacum Middle School. I am ready and my team here at Chimacum Middle School is ready. The other schools in our district are waiting. We just need the funds to get started and help our students succeed to make this world a better place.

      Risks & Challenges

      With our Plan A, equip every student and teacher in Chimacum Middle School, Plan B, equip every student and teacher in our 6th grade alone, and Plan C, equip a small group of students who will learn and then teach the rest of the students and teachers when we do get the funds, our plan has a high rate for success. It will work.

      I have been using tablets, netbooks, laptops, and desktop computers with my students for years. I have a great network of teachers that I learn with and from to help me use technology to empower my students to learn in ways they will be learning and working after they graduate. I have led workshops and conferences sharing what I've learned with other teachers. I am ready and I am highly qualified to bring my school and my school district into the 21st Century! We just need the funds to jump start our plan so please help!

      Other Ways You Can Help

      If you can't invest by giving money to our cause please share this campaign. Help spread the word so that our small, rural district can get a jump start in helping all our children prepare for their futures!

story:
Eastern Mediterranean International School is a new international school of 140 people from 40 countries with the mission of making education a force for peace and sustainability in the Middle East. Of these 140 students, two of them transformed their dream into a reality and founded the EMIS’s Model United Nations Society, and began their journey in spreading the mission and goals of the UN across our community’s youth.

In the first year of the school’s existence, the EMIS MUN team trained for their first conference, TIMEMUN, which took place in February 2015. In TIMEMUN, our first conference, the 19 EMIS MUN delegates received 3 Best Delegates (first place in the committee) and 3 Honorable Mentions (second or third place in their committees), as well as the Best Overall Delegation Award for the whole delegation. Besides TIMEMUN, 4 students of our MUN team received 3 Best Delegate and one Honorable Mention in a conference in Haifa MUN.

Since then, our MUN team has been preparing for IMUN, a conference in Portugal enlisting 300 students from all over the world discussing topics such as: the refugee crisis, the rights of the sex workers, xenophobia and more. This conference would provide delegates with the unique opportunity of showcasing their public speaking abilities as well as their knowledge and awareness of issues of global magnitude.  

The EMIS MUN team is a dynamic, exciting team with high skills in debate and public speaking and a huge interest in today’s world issues. EMIS is building the future generation of leaders and people which are going to change the world and better it. Our participation in the conference would bring this team, composed of Israelis, Palestinians and internationals in an exciting, professional environment.

Currently, funding is the biggest obstacle in the fulfilling of our dream, and this is where we need your help. The amount specified would help us pay the flight tickets (approx. 400 $ per person), participation fee (approx. 100$ per person), as well as accommodation for around 4 days (approx. 100 $ per person). The amount we specified would allow for sending of 6 of our teammates, yet with greater financial leeway, on behalf of your generosity, we could send even more delegates to represent our cause.

One of the challenges we are facing at the moment is the gathering of the funds in the short amount of time we have left before the registration needs to be finalized, in order for us to start researching and give our best in preparing for the conference. We believe that in today’s world, there is a need to invest and youth to enable platforms for dialogue and cooperation, as well as constructive exchange between countries.

Help us spread the word of EMIS MUN and our vision by sharing this campaign using the Indiegogo tools. Your help is immensely appreciated and every little effort counts!

Thank you very much!

story:
A Message From Bobs & LoLo


When we first met at a summer camp, we knew right away we had a lot in common. We both loved to sing and we both loved the outdoors. Growing up together, we continued to share a love of the natural world alongside a passion for working with children. Creating Bobs & LoLo has allowed us to combine our diverse academic backgrounds with a mutual love of teaching and the creative arts. 

Last year, we were excited to publish our first children’s book, Run Salmon Run, which is now paired with an original song under the same name on our latest album - Dirty Feet (watch the music video below).


As we explore new ways to further share our messages with young audiences, we are incredibly excited about our newest project. The Run Salmon Run App embraces all that we deem important in children’s media and entertainment...it is educational, meaningful and fun!

With your help we will be able to share this innovative learning tool with children, families, educators and schools everywhere. Salmon truly are key for the health of our coastal eco-systems. Please help us connect children with the salmon story and empower the next generation with the knowledge to become amazing ambassadors for these special fish and the environment.


The Nitty Gritty Details

We need to raise $20,000 to create the Run Salmon Run App and get it into the hands of kids and educators.The software development for our app design will cost approximately $15,000. The rest of the funds will go towards marketing - reaching out to elementary schools, preschools, libraries, nature centres and more. One of our goals is to keep the app affordable so that it can be accessible to all of these groups. Your support will help make this possible.


We are committed to avoiding any in-app purchases or advertisements. Our hope is to price the app at $2.49 or less. Money from sales will also go towards upgrades and creating an android version.

In exchange for your support, we are offering some fun perks - alongside our heartfelt gratitude! Please check out the donations page for more info on all the fun packages.

If we are unsuccessful in reaching our target, we will continue efforts to fund the app through other initiatives and partnerships. We are starting here on Indiegogo in an effort to keep our overhead low and allow us to achieve our goal of bringing the app to the market at an affordable price. 


Making A Difference

Not only are salmon an important part of our coastal ecosystems, but the salmon life cycle is a key part of the primary school curriculum in British Columbia. We have designed the app in consultation with science educators ensuring that the interactivity and educational components tie in seamlessly with curriculum learning objectives.

A concept image for the Run Salmon Run App's "play and learn" feature.


The Run Salmon Run book has already been a huge success. We have sold close to 1000 units and donated more than 500 copies to schools, libraries, salmon hatcheries, nature centres, children’s hospitals and various programs for children and families at risk.



We will also pledge 5% of all proceeds from the purchase of the app towards the Pacific Salmon Foundation and their ongoing efforts to support the restoration and enhancement of wild salmon habitat. 


Risks & Challenges

There is always risk when trying something new, but one thing we’ve learned over the past 15 years, is that by surrounding ourselves with a team of motivated and passionate individuals, dreams can be fulfilled. We have so much to celebrate in our creative lives beginning with our first album in 2004 to the launch of a musical preschool series on national television in 2009 to our first children’s book in 2014 and everything else in between. 

We know firsthand that it takes a team to make these things happen, and we ask you to please join our team! With your help and the expert support of Turtlebox Productions and Box of Frogs Media, the Run Salmon Run App will become an invaluable teaching tool and a truly important asset in the world of salmon education. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We understand that sometimes you don’t have any extra money to give, but you can still help us by sharing this campaign. Please tell your friends, tell your family, tell your coworkers and children's teachers and share away on social media. 

Thank you in advance for your time and support!   <*)))<

lot in common. We both loved to sing and we both loved the outdoors. Growing up
together, we continued to share a love of the natural world alongside a passion

mutual love of teaching and the creative arts. 
Last year, we
were excited to publish our first children’s book, Run Salmon Run, which is now
paired with an original song under the same name on our latest album - Dirty Feet (watch the music video below). 

As we explore new ways to further share our messages with young
audiences, we are incredibly excited about our newest project. The Run Salmon Run App embraces all that we deem important in children’s media and
entertainment...it is educational, meaningful and fun! 
With your help
we will be able to share this innovative learning tool with children, families,
educators and schools everywhere. Salmon truly are key for the health of our coastal
eco-systems. Please help us connect children with the salmon story and empower
the next generation with the knowledge to become amazing ambassadors for these
special fish and the environment. 

  
The Nitty Gritty Details
We need to raise $20,000 to create the Run Salmon Run App and get it into the hands of kids and educators.The software development for our app design will cost
approximately $15,000. The rest of the funds will go towards marketing -
reaching out to elementary schools, preschools, libraries, nature centres and
more. One of our goals is to keep the app affordable so that it can be
accessible to all of these groups. Your support will help make this possible.



We are committed to avoiding any in-app
purchases or advertisements. Our hope is to price the app at $2.49 or less. Money from sales will also go towards upgrades and
creating an android version.


In exchange for your support, we are offering some fun perks - alongside our heartfelt gratitude! Please check out the donations page for more info on all the fun packages.
If we are unsuccessful in reaching our target, we will continue efforts to fund the app through other initiatives and partnerships. We are starting here on Indiegogo in an effort to keep our overhead low and allow us to achieve our goal of bringing the app to the market at an affordable price. 

Making A Difference
Not only are salmon an important part of our coastal ecosystems, but
the salmon life cycle is a key part of the primary school curriculum in British
Columbia. We have designed the app in consultation with science educators
ensuring that the interactivity and educational components tie in seamlessly
with curriculum learning objectives.

A concept image for the Run Salmon Run App's "play and learn" feature.

The Run Salmon Run book has
already been a huge success. We have sold close to 1000 units and donated more
than 500 copies to schools, libraries, salmon hatcheries, nature centres,
children’s hospitals and various programs for children and families at risk.






We will
also pledge 5% of all proceeds from the purchase of the app towards the Pacific Salmon Foundation and their ongoing efforts to
support the restoration and enhancement of wild salmon habitat. 





Risks & Challenges
There
is always risk when trying something new, but one thing we’ve learned over the
past 15 years, is that by surrounding ourselves with a team of motivated and
passionate individuals, dreams can be fulfilled. We have so much to celebrate
in our creative lives beginning with our first album in 2004 to the launch of a
musical preschool series on national television in 2009 to our first children’s
book in 2014 and everything else in between. We know firsthand that it takes a
team to make these things happen, and we ask you to please join our team! With
your help and the expert support of Turtlebox Productions and Box of Frogs Media, the
Run Salmon Run App will become an invaluable teaching tool and a truly important
asset in the world of salmon education. 

Other Ways You Can Help
We understand that sometimes you don’t have any extra money to give,
but you can still help us by sharing this campaign. Please tell your friends,
tell your family, tell your coworkers and children's teachers and share away on social media. 
Thank you in advance for your
time and support!   <*)))<

story:
In March 2016, I have been offered the chance to join the 2041 International Antarctic Expedition leaving from Ushuaia in Argentina and sailing down the Antarctic Peninsula. 

As part of the expedition I will participate in the 'Leadership on the Edge' programme devised and delivered by Polar Medal recipient Robert Swan which will involve conducting research on the performance of small groups operating in extreme, unusual and isolated environments. The unique international nature of this expedition provides a rare opportunity to study group cohesion in a culturally-diverse set of individuals, who have never met before and who will be operating in stressful conditions. The findings will tell us more about the different personality factors and coping strategies used by individuals and groups when managing challenging events. Such research, and the information gained from it, is so important for preparing international expedition groups for travel into extreme environments, especially as journeys to remote parts of the Earth and beyond are becoming increasingly more available. 

With developments in technology, it is now possible to create an immersive and real-time account of experiences and allows supporters to share in the expedition and research activities from the all over the world. Before, during and after the expedition I will keep a video diary (think Mark Watney in The Martian!) and regular research blog where sponsors will be personally thanked and acknowledged. 

The chance the collect data in the field and conduct ethnographic research in Antarctica is not one I thought would ever happen. If you support this amazing opportunity and contribute to the research activities being undertaken I will do my best to share these moments with you, or involve you or your organisation in it.  Alongside my own savings and backing of the University of Northampton, your support would cover some of the logistical costs, the research equipment needed for the project and allow us to share the findings. 

Below is a little more information on the expedition and a link to the 2041 website.  

Please do get in touch at nathan.smith@northampton.ac.uk or via twitter @PsychEd4Sport if you want to know more about the expedition. I am happy to chat about ways to be involved in the expedition and to ensure sponsors get the most out of their support. 

Thank you so much for considering this campaign. 

2041:

The International Antarctic Expedition 2016, which hosts Robert Swan’s Leadership on the Edge program, will be an exhilarating and unpredictable adventure – a life changing experience for the international group of men and women joining Robert Swan and the 2041 Team to the last great wilderness on earth.

Antarctica provides a unique setting for this particular Expedition, bringing together people from across the globe to debate, discuss and determine firsthand the effects of climate change. Together with a team of expert lecturers, there will be an opportunity to see the effects of temperature rise on this icy and remote continent.

As a team, we will work together to create change in our families, companies, communities and countries. We will provide information, knowledge and insight from around the world to forge new relationships.

http://2041.com

story:
"The Skin I'm In" at LoveWorks Academy

LoveWorks Academy for Visual and Performing Arts is a K-8 charter school serving students in north Minneapolis, Minnesota. Last year, while reading "The Skin I'm In" by Sharon Flake, middle school students were inspired to write and perform a play based on the novel. Students wrote, edited, choreographed, rehearsed, designed, and performed the play as a work-in-progress last spring. This year, students are excited to share a full production with their families and the north Minneapolis community. 


What We Need & What You Get

Our goal is $2,500. Funds raised will be used to hire a composer and director to help students shape their initial ideas into a full professional production to be performed at the Capri Theater in north Minneapolis. Costumes, set, props, and theater and equipment rental will also be covered by donations.

Donors who give $25 or more will receive a photo signed by the cast.

Donors who give $50 or more will receive a signed photo and 2 free tickets to the show.

Donors who give $100 or more will receive a signed photo, 4 free tickets, and a LoveWorks t-shirt.

Donors who give $250 or more will receive a signed photo, 4 free tickets, a LoveWorks t-shirt, and a special shoutout at the end of the show.


The Impact

This production gives students the opportunity to share their talents with their community while being empowered to explore the issues of bullying and the challenge of finding self-love, which students experience on a daily basis.


Risks & Challenges

The biggest challenge we have to overcome is helping students to understand the discipline and focus it takes to put on a large-scale and professional production.

Other Ways You Can Help

Please share this link and our story with others, to help spread the word about the work LoveWorks Academy students are doing!

story:
The Musical Theory 2 F.A.M.E


Who are we?                        

The Foundation 2 F.A.M.E is a 501(c)(3) youth empowerment agency designed to support, motivate, and uplift the inner city’s youth. Geared towards teens of underdeveloped communities, The Foundation 2 F.A.M.E is launching The Musical Theory 2 F.A.M.E project. Which, harnesses musical and artistic expression to offer teens a reminder that their future isn’t dictated by present circumstances. While earning a stipend for their efforts, all participants will gain substantial exposure to the realms of creativity and education. From promoting scholastic excellence, leadership, entrepreneurialism, business etiquette, financial literacy and all areas in between The Musical Theory 2 F.A.M.E will be the source of providing teens with the intangibles to obtain all their aspirations.

The Musical Theory 2 F.A.M.E project will start from June, 1st 2016 through August, 1st 2016. In order for participants to attend The Musical theory program, specific requirements and guidelines must be met. All participants must maintain a specific GPA within their educational institution and adhere to a strict code of conduct. Confident with the success of the 1st year trial run, the board members of The Foundation 2 F.A.M.E believe there will be many more years to come. The Foundation 2 F.A.M.E strives to mold the leaders of tomorrow by challenging participants to Follow, Aspire, Multiply, and Elevate themselves today.                                                      


The Vision                       

Our vision is to change our communities through engagement. Music and art have the capacity to bring all walks of life together, therefore; the impact it would leave on a community is infinite. With unemployment, violence, and crime at alarming rates, we aim to show our youth numerous ways to channel their energy into something positive and worthwhile. Our foundation diligently aims to make leaders of society by providing a sanctuary for the inner city’s diamonds in the rough. We envision facilitating Business workshops, financial literacy and music centers to equip participants with tools needed to reach heights they never dreamed of. Show your support by donating to art, education, and cultural preservation for our youth.                        


The Necessities

The operational side of such a program requires a significant amount of manpower, facilities, and equipment. In order to achieve the goals, set by The Musical Theory 2 F.A.M.E, a $100,000 would be required to fulfill this initiative. Donated funds would be distributed through the program in many areas such as Stipends for students, Renovation of recording facility, transportation, Compensation for coordinators, new equipment for students and much more.

Contributions will not only play a significant role in the short term goals of The Musical Theory 2 F.A.M.E, but it would secure the programs longevity. With the projected success that this program will garner, The Musical Theory 2 F.A.M.E intends to go on a worldwide scale. Rewards for donations will be reciprocated, however no reward of monetary value can be equal to the impact of each donation provided.

Stipend for Students - ($35,000)

Legalities for the Program - ($2,000)

Renovation of existing Recording Facility; Creation of larger Second Location - ($15,000)

Compensation Program Staff - ($20,000)

Equipment for Students - ($28,000)

story:
Nawadih Youth Education is a small school in the village of Nawadih outside of Bodhgaya India. The village has very little supplies and works hard each day to continue living and without an education, the children of this village will have no possibility at a future outside of this impoverished community. Founder and Nawadih native, Navin Kumar, aims to change this.

Navin narrowly escaped these clutches through the rare chance of education when he was a boy. The school is simple and not much is needed to help these children, a little bit of money can go a long way here in Nawadih. The money raised will go to providing simple things like books, pencils, and paper as well as paying a very modest salary to teachers. Currently, N.Y.E. can only support 50-60 students in an area with 500 kids that would love to learn.

It doesn't take much from supporters to completely transform the precious lives of these eager children. Even a small contribution can go a long way. Thank you for your love and support in realizing the importance of knowledge and the future of these lives. 

Namaste.

story:
In 2005, The School of Art and Open Studio of Perquín was established in Perquín, El Salvador. A core group of community members, who became the school's teachers, felt a mandate to contribute to the reconstruction of a region that had been torn apart by 12 years of civil war in the 1980's and 1990's.

Through the creation of art projects involving children, youth, adults, and the elderly, the teachers worked to alleviate the traumas of war.


These diverse projects were always collaborative, and often involved the creation of large murals by the entire community.

Over the past decade, The School of Art has used "The Perquín Model" as it has expanded its reach into countries around the world, including Guatemala, Northern Ireland, Colombia, and many others. The School works in collaboration with human rights organizations, NGOs, universities, and local health units.

Led by artist Claudia Bernardi, the creation of "Walls of Hope" murals has facilitated community building and established bridges of diplomacy in societies suffering state terror, violations of human rights, and forced exile. 

The Perquín Model has been welcomed by victims of violence who find in the creation of collaborative art projects a way to retain and disseminate their silenced voices and never-spoken histories, and to move forward in community development.


Recently, our home base, The School of Art in Perquín, has been facing its most significant challenge to date.  Increased violence caused by growth of an economy based on narco trafficking has threatened the stability of the communities in northern El Salvador -- communities that are also being affected by a constant exodus of youth who seek safety by making the long journey as undocumented, unaccompanied minors towards the United States.

It is within this climate that the School has been invited to develop a second location in the current relative stability of Bogotá. 

Fe y Alegría, Schools that Change the World, an international agency that supports high-quality education as a tool for social transformation, has invited the School of Art to replicate the Perquín Model in Bogotá, Colombia.  (See more of what they do at http://www.feyalegria.org/en#.)

Fe y Alegría has agreed to provide room and board for a year to three artist- teachers from the School of Art in Perquín -- but additional funds are needed for living stipends, art supplies and materials, and transportation. 

The School of Art in Perquín will “nest” in Bogotá, Colombia, starting in November 2015, for an initial period of one year.

Three teachers from the School (America Argentina Vaquerano Romero, Claudia Verenice Flores Escolero and Rosa del Carmen Argueta) will lead workshops and classes with a range of local schools, community organizations, children’s advocacy groups and women’s cooperatives. We will develop workshops that use recycled material for collaborative art projects. We will aim to work with agencies that congregate kids at risk for projects similar to the ones we created in Perquin.

Founder and Artistic Director Claudia Bernardi will join the Salvadoran teachers from June to December 2016.

To make this year-long residency possible, The School of Art has a minimum need for $22,600.  Here's how our funding goal breaks down:

Salaries

Three Artist-Teachers, $400 per month each, for 12 months

Total   $ 14,400

Art Materials and Studio Costs

Mural paints, brushes, drawing and art materials for children and youth projects; Internet; incidentals

Total  $ 5,100

Transportation

Travel to mural sites and meetings with participants (public transportation within Bogotá)

Total  $ 500

(Total Operating Budget = $20,000)

Indiegogo & Bank Fees, Fiscal Sponsorship Fee   $ 2,600

GRAND TOTAL OF FUNDS NEEDED    $ 22,600

The money will be handled and administered through our fiscal sponsor, Intersection for the Arts, which is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization.  This means your donations are 100% tax-deductible!

We have lots of wonderful perks to offer our donors, such as hand-crafted jewelry by Rosa del Carmen...

...and beautiful poster prints, like this one, by Claudia Bernardi!

The mission of the School of Art in Perquín and Walls of Hope is to facilitate community-based projects that engage children, youth, and adults in the making of art that serves as a component of community-building.

These projects are created directly by participants on whom trauma, violence, and prejudice have been inflicted through political duress, state terror, wars and/or armed conflicts. The participants decide on the theme and narration of each piece with the intention of producing a visual testimony representing their recent history.

These collaborative art projects expand from creativity towards diplomacy and the demand for respect for human rights. Our work is political, but not partisan.


The community art projects created via the Perquín Model focus on the challenges posed by intercommunal and societal conflicts in today’s world. Our projects instill artistic skills and practical expertise in participants, in a new model of art education.
The School of Art in Perquín envisions a new methodology for peace-building and transitional justice through the praxis of beauty and the tenacity of hope.

This “nesting” of the School in Bogotá is the first step towards disseminating the Perquín Model throughout Latin America.

Our model of arts education and transitional justice has proved effective in countries around the world since 2005.  It's a powerful method of bringing communities together and bridging the deep divides born of war and trauma. 

But El Salvador is on track to become the "deadliest peace-time country in the world" (AP, 2015).  Gang violence has erupted after the collapse of a 2012 truce between gangs brokered by the Salvadoran government.  Homicides now average 15 per day in the capital.


We request your help to establish a second, more stable base for our school in Colombia, so that we may carry on our work in the hope of establishing strategies for conflict resolution in El Salvador and other suffering communities in the future.

Here's some of the work we've done in the past:

  • Antigua, Guatemala, February 2007

Mural project created by indigenous survivors of massacres of Ixcan, Ixil, Nebaj, Chimaltenango and Chajul.


  • Sacramento, California, US, October - December 2007

Mural project and video documentary created by African-American and Latino youth at inner-city Sacramento High School.

  • Guatemala City, January 2008

Mural project created by indigenous survivors of massacres in Ixcan and Quiche working collaboratively with human rights advocates members of ECAP (Equipo Comunitario de Acción Psicosocial).

  • Toronto, Canada, April -May 2008

Walls of Hope:  Installation: Sculptures, Paintings, Video, Dance, Theatre, Spoken Word created by recent refugee youth.

  • Huehuetenango, Guatemala, August 2008

Mural project created by indigenous women survivors of sexual violence during the armed conflict.

  • Cobán, Guatemala, February 2009
Paper sculpture project created by indigenous women survivors of sexual violence and sexual slavery during the armed conflict.

  • Rabinal, Guatemala, February 2009

Mural project created by indigenous survivors of torture and survivors of the massacres of Rabinal, Plan de Sánchez and Rio Negro.

  • Cocorná, Colombia, August, 2009

Mural project created with members of the Association of Victims of Violence and Forced Displacement of Cocorná, Antioquia.


  • Panzós, Guatemala, June-July 2010

Mural project created by the survivors of the massacre of Panzos, Alta Verapaz, thanks to a NALAC Transnational Cultural Remittance.

  • Belfast, Northern Ireland, September 2011

Collaborative, community-based mural project created by Catholic and Protestant children on the Ardoine Road, West Belfast, during the Ardoine riots.

  • Monthey, Switzerland, June 2012

Mural project created by 93 refugee, migrant and forced-exiled people from 25 different communities from Latin America, Africa and Eastern Europe.

  • Osnabruck, Germany, September 2012

Mural project created by 15 migrant women from Africa, Latin America, Eastern Europe and Mongolia, working in collaboration with 20 students of Social Work from the University of Osnabruck.


  • Staunton, Virginia, May 2013

Mural project created by African-American elders in collaboration with students and faculty from Mary Baldwin College.

  • Ciudad Juarez, Mexico, June 2013

Mural project created by 26 youth, ages 13 to 17, survivors of violence caused as result of the drug wars in Mexico.


  • Ciudad Juarez, Mexico, November 2013

Paper sculpture project with 28 youth affected by violence and drug wars in Mexico.

  •  “The Beast”, Virginia, USA, May 2014

Mural project created by undocumented, unaccompanied Central American minors, currently incarcerated in a juvenile center in the United States.

  • Ex ESMA, EX Clandestine Center of Detention and Extermination, Buenos Aires, Argentina, March 2014.

Mural project created by families of the "disappeared" who were able to retrieve the human remains of their loved ones thanks to the exhumations and DNA testing performed by the Argentine Forensic Anthropology Team.


  • Museum of Memory, La Plata, Buenos Aires, Argentina, October 2014

Mural project created by relatives of victims of recent police brutality in Argentina.

  • Part II, November, 2014: Ex ESMA, EX Clandestine Center of Detention and Extermination, Buenos Aires, Argentina, March 2014.

Mural project created by families of the "disappeared" who retrieved the human remains of their loved ones thanks to the AFAT.

  • Part III, November, 2014, EX ESMA

Mural project created by Mothers of Plaza de Mayo, Grandmothers of Plaza de Mayo, H.I.J.O.S, Administrators and Directors of the ESMA Cultural and Human Rights Center.

  • “The Tree of Life”, Virginia, USA, May 2015

Mural project created by unaccompanied undocumented incarcerated Central American minors, currently detained in a juvenile center in the United States.

If you're not able to contribute financially to our campaign, you can still help!  Please consider sharing our campaign on social media using the Indiegogo share tools, talking to people about it, or emailing the campaign link to anyone you know who is concerned with social and political justice and arts education.


*


Special Thanks to:

- Lysandra Petersson and Deep Structure Productions for designing this campaign and editing the video

- Josué Rojas and Benedicto Flanigan, who created the brief documentary about Perquín that is excerpted in the campaign video

- Rocomotion, the creators of the documentary about the mural at Ex ESMA, the clandestine center of detention, also excerpted in the campaign video

Walls of Hope is a CORE Member of Intersection for the Arts, the largest provider of fiscal sponsorship, incubation and consulting services to multi-disciplinary artists and arts organizations in the Bay Area. Visit www.theintersection.org.

The School works in collaboration with human rights organizations, NGOs, universities, and local health units.
Led by artist Claudia Bernardi, the creation of "Walls of Hope" murals has facilitated community building and established bridges of diplomacy in societies suffering state terror, violations of human rights, and forced exile.  
The Perquín Model has been welcomed by victims of violence who find in the creation of collaborative art projects a way to retain and disseminate their silenced voices and never-spoken histories, and to move forward in community development.









Recently, our home base, The School of Art in Perquín, has been facing its most significant challenge to
date.  Increased violence caused by
growth of an economy based on narco trafficking has threatened the stability of
the communities in northern El Salvador -- communities that are also being affected by a constant exodus of
youth who seek safety by making the long journey as undocumented, unaccompanied
minors towards the United States.
It
is within this climate that the School has been invited to develop a second
location in the current relative stability of Bogotá.  
Fe y Alegría, Schools that Change the
World, an international agency that supports high-quality
education as a tool for social transformation, has invited the School of Art to replicate the Perquín Model in Bogotá, Colombia.  (See more of what they do at http://www.feyalegria.org/en#.)
Fe y Alegría has agreed to provide room and board
for a year to three artist- teachers from the School of Art in Perquín -- but additional funds are needed for living stipends, art supplies and materials, and
transportation.  
  



The School of Art in Perquín will “nest” in Bogotá, Colombia,
starting in November 2015, for an initial period of one year.
Three
teachers from the School (America Argentina Vaquerano Romero, Claudia Verenice
Flores Escolero and Rosa del Carmen Argueta) will lead workshops and
classes with a range of local schools, community
organizations, children’s advocacy groups and women’s cooperatives. We will develop workshops that use recycled
 material for collaborative art projects. We will aim to work with agencies that congregate kids at 
risk for projects similar to the ones we created in 
Perquin.
Founder and
Artistic Director Claudia Bernardi will join the Salvadoran teachers
from June to December 2016.



To make this year-long residency possible, The School of Art has a minimum need for $22,600.  Here's how our funding goal breaks down: 
Salaries
Three Artist-Teachers,
$400 per month each, for 12 months
Total    $ 14,400
Art Materials and Studio Costs 
Mural paints, brushes, drawing and art materials for children and youth projects; Internet;
incidentals

Total  $ 5,100 

Transportation
Travel to mural sites and meetings with participants (public transportation within Bogotá)

Total  
$ 500
(Total Operating Budget = $20,000)
Indiegogo & Bank Fees, Fiscal Sponsorship Fee   $ 2,600
GRAND TOTAL OF FUNDS NEEDED    $
22,600
The money will be handled and administered through our fiscal sponsor, Intersection for the Arts, which is a 501(c)3 nonprofit organization.  This means your donations are 100% tax-deductible!We have lots of wonderful perks to offer our donors, such as hand-crafted jewelry by Rosa del Carmen...
...and beautiful poster prints, like this one, by Claudia Bernardi!
  
 
The
mission of the School of Art in Perquín and Walls of Hope is to facilitate community-based projects that engage children, youth, and adults in the making of art that serves as a component of community-building. 
These projects
are created directly by participants on whom trauma, violence, and prejudice have
been inflicted through political duress, state terror, wars and/or armed
conflicts. The participants decide on the theme and narration of each piece
with the intention of producing a visual testimony representing their recent
history.
These collaborative art projects
expand from creativity towards diplomacy and the demand for respect for human rights. Our work is political, but not
partisan.



The community art
projects created via the Perquín Model focus on the challenges posed by
intercommunal and societal conflicts in today’s world. Our
projects instill artistic skills and practical expertise in participants, in a new model of art
education.The School of
Art in Perquín envisions a new methodology for
peace-building and transitional justice through the praxis of beauty and the
tenacity of hope.This “nesting”
of the School in Bogotá is the first step towards disseminating the Perquín Model throughout Latin America.
  
Our model of arts education and transitional justice has proved 
effective in countries around the world since 2005.  It's a powerful 
method of bringing communities together and bridging the deep divides 
born of war and trauma.  But El Salvador is on track to become the "deadliest peace-time country in the world" (AP, 2015). 
 Gang violence has erupted after the collapse of a 2012 truce between 
gangs brokered by the Salvadoran government.  Homicides now average 15 
per day in the capital.
We request your help to establish a second, more stable base for our school in Colombia, so that we may carry on our work in the hope of establishing strategies for conflict resolution in El Salvador and other suffering communities in the future.



Here's some of the work we've done in the past:
Antigua, Guatemala, February 2007

Mural project created by indigenous survivors of massacres of Ixcan, Ixil,
     Nebaj, Chimaltenango and Chajul. 







Sacramento, California, US, October -
     December 2007
Mural project and video documentary created by African-American and Latino youth
     at inner-city Sacramento High School. 

Guatemala City, January 2008

Mural project created by indigenous survivors of massacres in Ixcan and Quiche
     working collaboratively with human rights advocates members of ECAP
     (Equipo Comunitario de Acción Psicosocial).
Toronto, Canada, April -May 2008
Walls of Hope:  Installation: Sculptures, Paintings, Video,
Dance, Theatre, Spoken Word created by recent refugee youth.

Huehuetenango, Guatemala, August 2008
Mural project
created by indigenous women
survivors of sexual violence during the armed conflict.
Cobán, Guatemala, February 2009Paper sculpture project created by
     indigenous women survivors of sexual
     violence and sexual slavery
     during the armed conflict.Rabinal, Guatemala, February 2009
Mural project created by indigenous survivors of
torture and survivors of the massacres of Rabinal, Plan de Sánchez and Rio
Negro.

Cocorná, Colombia, August, 2009

Mural project created with members of the Association of Victims of Violence and Forced Displacement of Cocorná,
     Antioquia.




Panzós, Guatemala, June-July 2010
Mural project created by the survivors of the massacre of Panzos, Alta Verapaz, thanks to a NALAC Transnational Cultural Remittance.

Belfast, Northern Ireland, September
     2011
Collaborative, community-based mural project
created by Catholic and Protestant children on the Ardoine Road, West Belfast,
during the Ardoine riots.
Monthey, Switzerland, June 2012
Mural project created by 93 refugee, migrant and
forced-exiled people from 25 different communities from Latin America, Africa
and Eastern Europe.
Osnabruck, Germany,
September 2012
Mural project created by 15 migrant women from
Africa, Latin America, Eastern Europe and Mongolia, working in collaboration with
20 students of Social Work from the University of Osnabruck.



Staunton, Virginia, May 2013
Mural project created by African-American elders in
collaboration with students and faculty from Mary Baldwin College.

Ciudad Juarez, Mexico, June 2013
Mural project created by 26 youth, ages 13 to 17,
survivors of violence caused as result of the drug wars in Mexico.




Ciudad Juarez, Mexico, November 2013

Paper sculpture project with 28 youth affected by violence and drug wars in Mexico.


 “The Beast”, Virginia,
USA, May 2014

Mural project created by undocumented,
unaccompanied Central American minors, currently incarcerated in a juvenile
center in the United States.
Ex ESMA, EX Clandestine Center of
     Detention and Extermination, Buenos Aires, Argentina, March 2014.
Mural project created by families of the "disappeared"
who were able to retrieve the human remains of their loved ones thanks to
the exhumations and DNA testing performed by the Argentine Forensic
Anthropology Team. 



Museum of Memory, La
Plata, Buenos Aires, Argentina, October 2014
Mural project created by relatives of victims of recent police brutality
in Argentina.

Part
     II, November, 2014: Ex ESMA, EX
     Clandestine Center of Detention and Extermination, Buenos Aires,
     Argentina, March 2014.
Mural project created by families of the "disappeared"
who retrieved the human remains of their loved ones thanks to the AFAT.
Part III, November, 2014,
EX ESMA
Mural
project created by Mothers of Plaza de Mayo, Grandmothers of Plaza de Mayo, H.I.J.O.S,
Administrators and Directors of the ESMA Cultural and Human Rights Center.


“The Tree of Life”,
Virginia, USA, May 2015

Mural project created by unaccompanied
undocumented incarcerated Central American minors, currently detained in a
juvenile center in the United States.


  
 If you're not able to contribute financially to our campaign, you can still help!  Please consider sharing our campaign on social media using the Indiegogo share tools, talking to people about it, or emailing the campaign link to anyone you know who is concerned with social and political justice and arts education.

*

Special Thanks to: 
- Lysandra Petersson and Deep Structure Productions for designing this campaign and editing the video
- Josué Rojas and Benedicto Flanigan, who created the brief documentary about Perquín that is excerpted in the campaign video 
- Rocomotion, the creators of the documentary about the mural at Ex ESMA, the clandestine center of detention, also excerpted in the campaign videoWalls of Hope is a CORE Member of Intersection
 for the Arts, the largest provider of fiscal sponsorship, incubation and consulting 
services to multi-disciplinary artists and arts organizations in the Bay Area. Visit www.theintersection.org.

story:
One year ago Nepal experienced a devastating earthquake that left the country of over 27 million people in shambles. In the already destitute region, the effects were profound.  Currently, 21 percent of people in Nepal live within the UN’s definition of extreme poverty and 17 percent live on less than $1 a day.  After traveling to Nepal and witnessing the destruction firsthand, our directors developed a strong desire to work with the people of Nepal by providing resources that will allow them to build themselves out of poverty.




Seva is designed to cater to a demand generated by the booming software market while providing education, job security, and opportunities to the villages and people of Nepal.  For every software program that is created, the software program has to be tested for glitches. This testing process is extremely expensive and tedious. Currently, companies spend an average of 35% of their technology budget on testing.  






 So how will Seva meet the high demand for software testing while benefiting the people of Nepal?  Our mission is to train recent graduates from local Nepalese villages in software testing.  Companies will receive software testing at an affordable cost, and Nepalese graduates interested in our program will have the opportunity to earn a substantial living, develop technical skills, and give back to their communities.  In order to make a social impact, we have partnered with CHOICE Humanitarian (http://www.choicehumanitarian.org).  CHOICE Humanitarian has been working with the people of Nepal to alleviate extreme poverty in 180 villages for over 15 years.  As part of our social mission, we will donate money to CHOICE’s village development team who will effectively allocate funds within the community.

  Where will your donations go?  With your generous help we will be able to secure the capital needed to begin helping the people of Nepal.  Your donations will allow us to renovate the initial facility, install solar panels, provide computers for our engineers, as well as hire and employ a greater number of students and trainers.





Thus far, with the help of CHOICE’s in-country team, we have secured our first software testing and training facility in Duradanda-Lamjung, Nepal.  We have hired a Nepalese software tester who will provide training to our engineers and oversee the in-country facility.  So far, we have interest from high school graduates in the community as well as university graduates in Phokara and Kathmandu. Domestically, our team is working to (http://www.sevadevelopment.com) secure our first clientele.




  Our goal is to create opportunities for the people of Nepal to receive quality education and build themselves out of poverty. With Seva Development, workers will receive high salaries and villages will receive donations to stimulate their economy and rebuild infrastructure that was devastated by the earthquake. Together, with your generous donations, we can help provide the resources necessary to make a substantial change in the lives of the wonderful people of Nepal.



Thank you for your support!
